**Amsterdam** ([/ˈæmstərdæm/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*AM-stər-dam*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"), [UK](/wiki/British_English "British English") also [/ˌæmstərˈdæm/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*AM-stər-DAM*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key");^[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-:7-13)^
Dutch: [\[ˌɑmstərˈdɑm\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Dutch "Help:IPA/Dutch") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/c/cd/Nl-Amsterdam.ogg/Nl-Amsterdam.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Nl-Amsterdam.ogg "File:Nl-Amsterdam.ogg")^;  '[Dam](/wiki/Dam "Dam") in the [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel")')^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Amestelledamme1-14)^ is the capital^[\[a\]](#cite_note-15)^ and [most populated city](/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands"). It has a population of 933,680 in June 2024^[\[15\]](#cite_note-:8-16)^ within the city proper, 1,457,018 in the [urban area](/wiki/City_Region_of_Amsterdam "City Region of Amsterdam")^[\[15\]](#cite_note-:8-16)^ and 2,480,394 in the [metropolitan area](/wiki/Amsterdam_metropolitan_area "Amsterdam metropolitan area").^[\[16\]](#cite_note-osamsterdam2015-17)^ Located in the [Dutch province](/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Netherlands "Provinces of the Netherlands") of [North Holland](/wiki/North_Holland "North Holland"),^[\[17\]](#cite_note-R2040-18)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^ Amsterdam is colloquially referred to as the "[Venice of the North](/wiki/Venice_of_the_North "Venice of the North")", for its [large number of canals](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), now a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site").^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}

Amsterdam was founded at the mouth of the [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel") River, which was dammed to control flooding.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-:9-21)^ Originally a small fishing village in the 12th century, Amsterdam became a major world port during the [Dutch Golden Age](/wiki/Dutch_Golden_Age "Dutch Golden Age") of the 17th century, when the Netherlands was an economic powerhouse. Amsterdam was the leading centre for finance and trade, as well as a hub of secular art production.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^ In the 19th and 20th centuries, the city expanded and new neighborhoods and suburbs were built. The city has a long tradition of openness, liberalism, and tolerance.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^ [Cycling](/wiki/Cycling_in_the_Netherlands "Cycling in the Netherlands") is key to the city's modern character, and there are numerous [biking paths and lanes](/wiki/Cycling_infrastructure "Cycling infrastructure") spread throughout.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^{#cite_ref-25}

[Amsterdam's main attractions](/wiki/List_of_tourist_attractions_in_Amsterdam "List of tourist attractions in Amsterdam") include its [historic canals](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"); the [Rijksmuseum](/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum"), the state museum with Dutch Golden Age art; the [Van Gogh Museum](/wiki/Van_Gogh_Museum "Van Gogh Museum"); the [Dam Square](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"), where the [Royal Palace of Amsterdam](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam") and former city hall are located; the [Amsterdam Museum](/wiki/Amsterdam_Museum "Amsterdam Museum"); [Stedelijk Museum](/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam"), with modern art; the [Concertgebouw](/wiki/Concertgebouw,_Amsterdam "Concertgebouw, Amsterdam") concert hall; the [Anne Frank House](/wiki/Anne_Frank_House "Anne Frank House"); the [Scheepvaartmuseum](/wiki/Het_Scheepvaartmuseum "Het Scheepvaartmuseum"), the [Natura Artis Magistra](/wiki/Natura_Artis_Magistra "Natura Artis Magistra"); [Hortus Botanicus](/wiki/Hortus_Botanicus_Amsterdam "Hortus Botanicus Amsterdam"), [NEMO](/wiki/NEMO_(museum) "NEMO (museum)"), the [red-light district](/wiki/Red-light_district "Red-light district") and [cannabis coffee shops](/wiki/Coffeeshop_(Netherlands) "Coffeeshop (Netherlands)"). The city is known for its nightlife and festival activity, with several nightclubs among the world's most famous. Its artistic heritage, canals, and narrow canal houses with gabled [façades](/wiki/Facade "Facade"), well-preserved legacies of the city's 17th-century Golden Age, have attracted millions of visitors annually.

The [Amsterdam Stock Exchange](/wiki/Amsterdam_Stock_Exchange "Amsterdam Stock Exchange"), founded in 1602, is considered the oldest "modern" securities market [stock exchange](/wiki/Stock_exchange "Stock exchange") in the world. As the commercial capital of the Netherlands and one of the top [financial centres](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") in Europe, Amsterdam is considered an [alpha-world city](/wiki/Alpha-world_city "Alpha-world city"). The city is the cultural capital of the Netherlands.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^ Many large Dutch institutions have their headquarters in the city.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-27)^ Many of the world's largest companies are based here or have established their European headquarters in the city, such as technology companies [Uber](/wiki/Uber "Uber"), [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix"), and [Tesla](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^ In 2022, Amsterdam was ranked the ninth-best city to live in by the [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit")^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ and 12th on quality of living for environment and infrastructure by Mercer.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^ The city was ranked 4th place globally as a top tech hub in 2019.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^ The [Port of Amsterdam](/wiki/Port_of_Amsterdam "Port of Amsterdam") is the fifth largest in Europe.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-RPA_Stat15-32)^ The [KLM](/wiki/KLM "KLM") hub and Amsterdam's main airport, [Schiphol](/wiki/Amsterdam_Airport_Schiphol "Amsterdam Airport Schiphol"), is the [busiest airport in the Netherlands](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_the_Netherlands "List of the busiest airports in the Netherlands"), [third in Europe](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe "List of the busiest airports in Europe"), and [11th in the world](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports "List of the busiest airports").^[\[32\]](#cite_note-BestGlobal-33)^ The Dutch capital is one of the most multicultural cities in the world, with about 180 nationalities represented.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)^ Immigration and ethnic segregation in Amsterdam is a current issue.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^{#cite_ref-35}

Amsterdam's notable residents throughout [its history](/wiki/History_of_Amsterdam "History of Amsterdam") include painters [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt") and [Vincent van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh"), 17th-century philosophers [Baruch Spinoza](/wiki/Baruch_Spinoza "Baruch Spinoza"), [John Locke](/wiki/John_Locke "John Locke"), [René Descartes](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes "René Descartes"), and [the Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust") victim and diarist [Anne Frank](/wiki/Anne_Frank "Anne Frank").  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Amsterdam](/wiki/History_of_Amsterdam "History of Amsterdam")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Amsterdam](/wiki/Timeline_of_Amsterdam "Timeline of Amsterdam").  

### Prehistory {#Prehistory}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Prehistory")\]

Due to its geographical location in what used to be wet [peatland](/wiki/Mire "Mire"), the founding of Amsterdam is later than other [urban centres in the Low Countries](/wiki/History_of_urban_centers_in_the_Low_Countries "History of urban centers in the Low Countries"). However, around the area of what later became Amsterdam, farmers settled as early as three millennia ago. They lived along the prehistoric [IJ](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") river and upstream of its [tributary](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary") Amstel. The prehistoric IJ was a shallow and quiet stream in peatland behind [beach ridges](/wiki/Beach_ridge "Beach ridge"). This secluded area was able to grow into an important local settlement centre, especially in the late [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age_Europe "Bronze Age Europe"), the [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age_Europe "Iron Age Europe") and the [Roman Age](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"). [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") and Roman artefacts have also been found in the prehistoric [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel") bedding under Amsterdam's [Damrak](/wiki/Damrak "Damrak") and [Rokin](/wiki/Rokin "Rokin"), such as shards of [Bell Beaker culture](/wiki/Bell_Beaker_culture "Bell Beaker culture") [pottery](/wiki/Pottery "Pottery") (2200--2000 BC) and a granite grinding stone (2700--2750 BC),^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ but the location of these artefacts around the river banks of the Amstel probably points to the presence of a modest semi-permanent or seasonal settlement. Until water issues were controlled, a permanent settlement would not have been possible, since the river mouth and the banks of the Amstel in this period in time were too wet for permanent habitation.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}  

### Founding {#Founding}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Founding")\]  
See also [Other names of Amsterdam](/wiki/Names_of_European_cities_in_different_languages:_A "Names of European cities in different languages: A")

The origins of Amsterdam are linked to the development of a dam on the [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel") River called *[Amestelle](/wiki/Amstelland "Amstelland")* , meaning 'watery area', from *[Aa(m)](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Aa "wikt:Aa")* 'river' + *[stelle](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stelling "wikt:stelling")* 'site at a shoreline', 'river bank'.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-:6-40)^ In this area, [land reclamation](/wiki/Land_reclamation "Land reclamation") started as early as the late 10th century.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ Amestelle was located along a side arm of the IJ. This sidearm took its name from the eponymous land: Amstel. Amestelle was inhabited by farmers, who lived more inland and more upstream, where the land was not as wet as at the banks of the downstream river mouth. These farmers were starting the reclamation around upstream [Ouderkerk aan de Amstel](/wiki/Ouderkerk_aan_de_Amstel "Ouderkerk aan de Amstel"), and later at the other side of the river at [Amstelveen](/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen"). The [Van Amstel family](/wiki/Van_Amstel_family "Van Amstel family"), known in documents by this name since 1019,^[\[39\]](#cite_note-:6-40)^ held the stewardship in this northwestern nook of the ecclesiastical district of the [bishop of Utrecht](/wiki/Prince-Bishopric_of_Utrecht "Prince-Bishopric of Utrecht"). The family later served also under the [count of Holland](/wiki/County_of_Holland "County of Holland").{#cite_ref-:6_40-1}

A major turning point in the development of the Amstel River mouth was the [All Saint's Flood of 1170](/wiki/All_Saints%27_Flood_(1170) "All Saints' Flood (1170)"). In an extremely short time, the shallow river IJ turned into a wide estuary, which from then on offered the Amstel an open connection to the [Zuiderzee](/wiki/Zuiderzee "Zuiderzee"), [IJssel](/wiki/IJssel "IJssel"), and waterways further afield. This made the water flow of the Amstel more active, so excess water could be drained better. With drier banks, the downstream Amstel mouth became attractive for permanent habitation. Moreover, the river had grown from an insignificant peat stream into a junction of international waterways.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^ A settlement was built here immediately after the landscape change of 1170. Right from the start of its foundation, it focused on traffic, production, and trade; not on farming, as opposed to how communities had lived further upstream for the past 200 years and northward for thousands of years.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^ The construction of a dam at the mouth of the Amstel, eponymously named [Dam](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"), is historically estimated to have occurred between 1264 and 1275. The settlement first appeared in a document from 1275, concerning a [road toll](/wiki/Road_toll_(historical) "Road toll (historical)") granted by the [count of Holland Floris V](/wiki/Floris_V,_Count_of_Holland "Floris V, Count of Holland") to the residents *apud Amestelledamme* 'at the dam in the Amstel' or 'at the dam of Amstelland'.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Amestelledamme1-14)^ This allowed the inhabitants of the village to travel freely through the [County of Holland](/wiki/County_of_Holland "County of Holland"), paying no tolls at bridges, locks and dams.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ This was a move in a years-long struggle for power in the area between the count of Holland and the Amstel family who governed the area on behalf of the bishop of Utrecht.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ By 1327, the name had developed into *Aemsterdam* .^[\[46\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBernsDaan199391-47)^^[\[47\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMak199418–20-48)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMak199418–20_48-0}  
See also: [van Dam](/wiki/Van_Dam "Van Dam")  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Amsterdam_%286578772447%29.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_%286578772447%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_(6578772447).jpg) The [Oude Kerk](/wiki/Oude_Kerk,_Amsterdam "Oude Kerk, Amsterdam") was consecrated in 1306 AD.

The bishop of Utrecht granted Amsterdam zone [rights](/wiki/City_rights_in_the_Low_Countries "City rights in the Low Countries") in either 1300 or 1306.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-amnlgeschedenis-49)^ The [Mirakel van Amsterdam](/w/index.php?title=Mirakel_van_Amsterdam&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mirakel van Amsterdam (page does not exist)") \[[nl](https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirakel_van_Amsterdam "nl:Mirakel van Amsterdam")\] in 1345 rendered the city an important place of [pilgrimage](/wiki/Pilgrimage "Pilgrimage"). During the heyday of the *[Stille Omgang](/wiki/Stille_Omgang "Stille Omgang")* , which became the expression of the pilgrimage after the [Protestant Reformation](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation "Protestant Reformation"),^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^^[\[50\]](#cite_note-stilleomgang-51)^ up to 90,000 pilgrims came to Amsterdam.{#cite_ref-stilleomgang_51-0}

From the 14th century on, Amsterdam flourished, largely from trade with the [Hanseatic League](/wiki/Hanseatic_League "Hanseatic League"). From the 15th century on the city established an independent [trade route with the Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_maritime_trade_(c._1400%E2%80%931800) "Baltic maritime trade (c. 1400–1800)") in grain and timber, cutting out the Hanseatic League as middlemen. The city became the staple market of Europe for [bulk cargo](/wiki/Bulk_cargo "Bulk cargo"). This was made possible due to innovations in the [herring fishery](/wiki/Herring "Herring"), from which Amsterdam reaped great wealth.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-:7-13)^ Herring had demand in markets all around Europe. Inventions of on-board [gibbing](/wiki/Gibbing "Gibbing") and the [haringbuis](/wiki/Herring_buss "Herring buss") in 1415, made longer voyages feasible and hence enabled Dutch fishermen to follow the herring [shoals](/wiki/Shoaling_and_schooling "Shoaling and schooling") far from the coasts, giving them a monopoly in the industry.{#cite_ref-:7_13-1}

The herring industry relied on international trade cooperation and large initial investments in ships. This required many highly skilled and unskilled workers to cooperate, as well as the import of the necessary raw materials to turn an unfinished product into a marketable one. This required merchants to then sell it throughout the continent and bookkeepers and accountants to divide the profit. In short, the herring industry was setting up the foundations for what would later become the transcontinental trade system and the [Dutch Golden Age](/wiki/Dutch_Golden_Age "Dutch Golden Age"), with Amsterdam at its centre,^[\[15\]](#cite_note-:8-16)^ hence the saying "Amsterdam is built on Herringbones".^[\[20\]](#cite_note-:9-21)^{#cite_ref-:9_21-1}  

### Conflict with Spain {#Conflict_with_Spain}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Conflict with Spain")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Bartholomeus_van_der_Helst%2C_Banquet_of_the_Amsterdam_Civic_Guard_in_Celebration_of_the_Peace_of_M%C3%BCnster.jpg/330px-Bartholomeus_van_der_Helst%2C_Banquet_of_the_Amsterdam_Civic_Guard_in_Celebration_of_the_Peace_of_M%C3%BCnster.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bartholomeus_van_der_Helst,_Banquet_of_the_Amsterdam_Civic_Guard_in_Celebration_of_the_Peace_of_M%C3%BCnster.jpg) Amsterdam citizens celebrating the [Peace of Münster](/wiki/Peace_of_M%C3%BCnster "Peace of Münster"), 30 January 1648. Painting by [Bartholomeus van der Helst](/wiki/Bartholomeus_van_der_Helst "Bartholomeus van der Helst")

The Low Countries were part of the Hapsburg inheritance and came under the Spanish monarchy in the early sixteenth century. The Dutch rebelled against [Philip II of Spain](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain"), who led a defense of Catholicism during the Protestant Reformation. The main reasons for the uprising were the imposition of new taxes, the tenth penny, and the [religious persecution](/wiki/Religious_persecution "Religious persecution") of Protestants by the newly introduced [Inquisition](/wiki/Inquisition_of_the_Netherlands "Inquisition of the Netherlands"). The revolt escalated into the [Eighty Years' War](/wiki/Eighty_Years%27_War "Eighty Years' War"), which ultimately led to Dutch independence.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-80yearswar-52)^ Strongly pushed by [Dutch Revolt](/wiki/Dutch_Revolt "Dutch Revolt") leader [William the Silent](/wiki/William_the_Silent "William the Silent"), the [Dutch Republic](/wiki/Dutch_Republic "Dutch Republic") became known for its relative [religious](/wiki/History_of_religion_in_the_Netherlands "History of religion in the Netherlands") tolerance. [Jews](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_the_Netherlands "History of the Jews in the Netherlands") from the [Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula"), Protestant [Huguenots](/wiki/Huguenot "Huguenot") from France, prosperous merchants, and printers from [Flanders](/wiki/Flanders "Flanders"), and economic and religious refugees from the Spanish-controlled parts of the [Low Countries](/wiki/Low_Countries "Low Countries") found safety in Amsterdam. The influx of Flemish printers and the city's intellectual tolerance made Amsterdam a centre for the European [free press](/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press "Freedom of the press").^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}  

### Centre of the Dutch Golden Age {#Centre_of_the_Dutch_Golden_Age}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Centre of the Dutch Golden Age")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/The_courtyard_of_the_Beurs_in_Amsterdam%2C_by_Emanuel_de_Witte.jpg/170px-The_courtyard_of_the_Beurs_in_Amsterdam%2C_by_Emanuel_de_Witte.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_courtyard_of_the_Beurs_in_Amsterdam,_by_Emanuel_de_Witte.jpg) Courtyard of the [Amsterdam Stock Exchange](/wiki/Amsterdam_Stock_Exchange "Amsterdam Stock Exchange") by [Emanuel de Witte](/wiki/Emanuel_de_Witte "Emanuel de Witte"), 1653. The [Amsterdam Stock Exchange](/wiki/Amsterdam_Stock_Exchange "Amsterdam Stock Exchange") was the first [stock exchange](/wiki/Stock_exchange "Stock exchange") to introduce continuous trade in the early 17th century.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-Braudel-54)^

During the 17th century, Amsterdam experienced what is considered its *[Golden Age](/wiki/Dutch_Golden_Age "Dutch Golden Age")* , during which it became the wealthiest city in the Western world.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^ Ships sailed from Amsterdam to the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"), the Caribbean, North America, and Africa, as well as present-day [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), India, [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"), and [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), forming the basis of a worldwide trading network. Amsterdam's merchants had the largest share in both the [Dutch East India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company "Dutch East India Company") (VOC) and the [Dutch West India Company](/wiki/Dutch_West_India_Company "Dutch West India Company"). These companies acquired overseas possessions that later became [Dutch colonies](/wiki/Dutch_Empire "Dutch Empire").{#cite_ref-55}

Amsterdam was Europe's most important hub for the shipment of goods and was the leading [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") of the Western world.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^ In 1602, the Amsterdam office of the Dutch East India Company became the world's first [stock exchange](/wiki/Stock_exchange "Stock exchange") by trading in its own shares.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-The_oldest_share-57)^ The Bank of Amsterdam started operations in 1609, acting as a full-service bank for Dutch merchant bankers and as a reserve bank.{#cite_ref-The_oldest_share_57-0}

From the 17th century onwards, Amsterdam also became involved in the [Atlantic slave trade](/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade "Atlantic slave trade"). The city was a major destination port for Dutch [slave ships](/wiki/Slave_ship "Slave ship") participating in the [triangular trade](/wiki/Triangular_trade "Triangular trade"), which lasted until the [United Netherlands](/wiki/Sovereign_Principality_of_the_United_Netherlands "Sovereign Principality of the United Netherlands") abolished the Netherlands' involvement in the trade in 1814 at the request of the [British government](/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom"). Amsterdam was also a member of the [Society of Suriname](/wiki/Society_of_Suriname "Society of Suriname"), an organisation founded to oversee the management of the Dutch colony of [Surinam](/wiki/Surinam_(Dutch_colony) "Surinam (Dutch colony)"), which was economically dependent on [slave plantations](/wiki/Slave_plantation "Slave plantation"). On 1 July 2021, the [mayor of Amsterdam](/wiki/Mayor_of_Amsterdam "Mayor of Amsterdam"), [Femke Halsema](/wiki/Femke_Halsema "Femke Halsema"), apologised for the city's involvement in the slave trade.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-58)^^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^{#cite_ref-59}  

### Decline and modernization {#Decline_and_modernization}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Decline and modernization")\]

Amsterdam's prosperity declined during the 18th and early 19th centuries. The [wars](/wiki/Anglo-Dutch_Wars "Anglo-Dutch Wars") of the [Dutch Republic](/wiki/Dutch_Republic "Dutch Republic") with [England](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of England") (latterly, [Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain")) and France took their toll on the city. During the [French Revolutionary Wars](/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars "French Revolutionary Wars") and the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars"), Amsterdam's significance reached its lowest point, with Holland being absorbed into the [French Empire](/wiki/First_French_Empire "First French Empire"). However, the later establishment of the [United Kingdom of the Netherlands](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands "United Kingdom of the Netherlands") in 1815 marked a turning point.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Old-Amsterdam_1891-street-1.jpg/170px-Old-Amsterdam_1891-street-1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Old-Amsterdam_1891-street-1.jpg) View of Vijzelstraat looking towards the [Muntplein](/wiki/Muntplein,_Amsterdam "Muntplein, Amsterdam"), 1891

The end of the 19th century is sometimes called Amsterdam's second Golden Age.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-Amsterdam_City_Walks-60)^ New museums, a railway station, and the [Concertgebouw](/wiki/Concertgebouw,_Amsterdam "Concertgebouw, Amsterdam") were built; At the same time, the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution") reached the city. The [Amsterdam--Rhine Canal](/wiki/Amsterdam%E2%80%93Rhine_Canal "Amsterdam–Rhine Canal") was dug to give Amsterdam a direct connection to the [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine"), and the [North Sea Canal](/wiki/North_Sea_Canal "North Sea Canal") was dug to give the port a shorter connection to the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea"). Both projects dramatically improved commerce with the rest of Europe and the world. In 1906, [Joseph Conrad](/wiki/Joseph_Conrad "Joseph Conrad") gave a brief description of Amsterdam as seen from the seaside, in *The Mirror of the Sea*.{#cite_ref-Amsterdam_City_Walks_60-0}  

### 20th century -- present {#20th_century_.E2.80.93_present}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: 20th century – present")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Amsterdam_photochrom2.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_photochrom2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_photochrom2.jpg) Photochrom of Amsterdam's [Dam Square](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square") at the beginning of the 20th century

Shortly before the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War"), the city started to expand again, and new suburbs were built. Even though the Netherlands remained neutral in this war, Amsterdam suffered a food shortage, and heating fuel became scarce. The shortages sparked riots in which several people were killed. These riots are known as the *Aardappeloproer* (Potato Rebellion). People started looting stores and warehouses to get supplies, mainly food.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-aardappeloproer-61)^{#cite_ref-aardappeloproer_61-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Jan_Philip_Albach%2C_Afb_ANWH00199000048.jpg/220px-Jan_Philip_Albach%2C_Afb_ANWH00199000048.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jan_Philip_Albach,_Afb_ANWH00199000048.jpg) The rebuilt [Magere Brug](/wiki/Magere_Brug "Magere Brug"), around 1938.

On 1 January 1921, after a flood in 1916, the depleted municipalities of Durgerdam, Holysloot, Zunderdorp and [Schellingwoude](/wiki/Schellingwoude "Schellingwoude"), all lying north of Amsterdam, were, at their own request, annexed to the city.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^^[\[62\]](#cite_note-63)^ Between the wars, the city continued to expand, most notably to the west of the [Jordaan](/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") district in the [Frederik Hendrikbuurt](/wiki/Frederik_Hendrikbuurt "Frederik Hendrikbuurt") and surrounding neighbourhoods.{#cite_ref-63}

[Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") [invaded the Netherlands](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Netherlands "Battle of the Netherlands") on 10 May 1940 and took control of the country. Some Amsterdam citizens sheltered Jews, thereby exposing themselves and their families to a high risk of being imprisoned or sent to concentration camps. More than 100,000 [Dutch Jews](/wiki/Dutch_Jews "Dutch Jews") were deported to [Nazi concentration camps](/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camps "Nazi concentration camps"), of whom some 60,000 lived in Amsterdam. In response, the Dutch Communist Party organized the [February strike](/wiki/February_strike "February strike") attended by 300,000 people to protest against the raids. The most famous deportee was the young Jewish girl [Anne Frank](/wiki/Anne_Frank "Anne Frank"), who died in the [Bergen-Belsen concentration camp](/wiki/Bergen-Belsen_concentration_camp "Bergen-Belsen concentration camp").^[\[63\]](#cite_note-deportation-64)^ At the end of the Second World War, communication with the rest of the country broke down, and food and fuel became scarce. Many citizens traveled to the countryside to forage. Dogs, cats, raw [sugar beets](/wiki/Sugar_beet "Sugar beet"), and [tulip](/wiki/Tulip "Tulip") bulbs---cooked to a pulp---were consumed to stay alive.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-hongerwinter-65)^ Many trees in Amsterdam were cut down for fuel, and wood was taken from the houses, apartments and other buildings of deported Jews. The city was finally liberated by Canadian forces on 5 May 1945, shortly before the end of the war in Europe.{#cite_ref-hongerwinter_65-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Enorme_menigte_op_de_Amstellaan_te_Amsterdam_Op_de_achtergrond_de_zgn_wolkenkrabber%2C_Bestanddeelnr_900-2830.jpg/170px-Enorme_menigte_op_de_Amstellaan_te_Amsterdam_Op_de_achtergrond_de_zgn_wolkenkrabber%2C_Bestanddeelnr_900-2830.jpg)](/wiki/File:Enorme_menigte_op_de_Amstellaan_te_Amsterdam_Op_de_achtergrond_de_zgn_wolkenkrabber,_Bestanddeelnr_900-2830.jpg) People celebrating the [liberation of the Netherlands](/wiki/Liberation_Day_(Netherlands) "Liberation Day (Netherlands)") at the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") on 8 May 1945

Many new suburbs, such as [Osdorp](/wiki/Osdorp "Osdorp"), [Slotervaart](/wiki/Slotervaart_(neighborhood) "Slotervaart (neighborhood)"), [Slotermeer](/wiki/Slotermeer "Slotermeer") and [Geuzenveld](/wiki/Geuzenveld "Geuzenveld"), were built in the years after the Second World War.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-svgeschedenis-66)^ These suburbs contained many public parks and wide-open spaces, and the new buildings provided improved housing conditions with larger and brighter rooms, gardens, and balconies. Because of the war and other events of the 20th century, almost the entire city centre had fallen into disrepair. As society was changing,^\[*[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^ politicians and other influential figures made plans to redesign large parts of it. There was an increasing demand for office buildings, and also for new roads, as the automobile became available to most people.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-stadsherstel-67)^ A [metro](/wiki/Amsterdam_Metro "Amsterdam Metro") started operating in 1977 between the new suburb of [Bijlmermeer](/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer") in the city's [Zuidoost](/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuidoost "Amsterdam-Zuidoost") (southeast) exclave and the centre of Amsterdam. Further plans were to build a new highway above the metro to connect [Amsterdam Centraal](/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_station "Amsterdam Centraal station") and the city centre with other parts of the city.{#cite_ref-stadsherstel_67-0}

The required large-scale demolitions began in Amsterdam's former Jewish neighborhood. Smaller streets, such as the Jodenbreestraat and Weesperstraat, were widened and almost all houses and buildings were demolished. At the peak of the demolition, the *Nieuwmarktrellen* ([Nieuwmarkt riots](/wiki/Nieuwmarkt_riots "Nieuwmarkt riots")) broke out;^[\[67\]](#cite_note-metrostad-68)^ the rioters expressed their fury about the demolition caused by the restructuring of the city.{#cite_ref-metrostad_68-0}

As a result, the demolition was stopped and the highway into the city's centre was never fully built; only the metro was completed. Only a few streets remained widened. The new city hall was built on the almost completely demolished Waterlooplein. Meanwhile, large private organizations, such as *Stadsherstel Amsterdam* , were founded to restore the entire city centre. Although the success of this struggle is visible today, efforts for further restoration are still ongoing.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-stadsherstel-67)^ The entire city centre has reattained its former splendour and, as a whole, is now a [protected area](/wiki/Protected_area "Protected area"). Many of its buildings have become monuments, and in July 2010 the [Grachtengordel](/wiki/Grachtengordel_(Amsterdam) "Grachtengordel (Amsterdam)") (the three concentric canals: Herengracht, Keizersgracht, and Prinsengracht) was added to the [UNESCO World Heritage List](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-unesco-69)^{#cite_ref-unesco_69-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Amsterdam_Canal_Tour.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_Canal_Tour.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Canal_Tour.jpg) The 17th-century [Canals of Amsterdam](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam") were listed as [UNESCO World Heritage Sites](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site") in 2010,^[\[69\]](#cite_note-70)^ contributing to Amsterdam's fame as the "[Venice of the North](/wiki/Venice_of_the_North "Venice of the North")".^[\[70\]](#cite_note-Venice1-71)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Venice3-72)^ Along with [De Wallen](/wiki/De_Wallen "De Wallen"), the canals are the focal point for tourists in the city.

In the 21st century, the Amsterdam city centre has attracted large numbers of tourists: between 2012 and 2015, the annual number of visitors rose from 10 to 17 million. Real estate prices have surged, and local shops are making way for tourist-oriented ones, making the centre unaffordable for the city's inhabitants.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ These developments have evoked comparisons with [Venice](/wiki/Venice_(Italy) "Venice (Italy)"), a city thought to be overwhelmed by the tourist influx.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}

Construction of a new metro line connecting the part of the city north of the [IJ](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") to its southern part was started in 2003. The project was controversial because its cost had exceeded its budget by a factor of three by 2008,^[\[74\]](#cite_note-75)^ because of fears of damage to buildings in the centre, and because construction had to be halted and restarted multiple times.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^ The new metro line was completed in 2018.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^{#cite_ref-77}

Since 2014, renewed focus has been given to urban regeneration and renewal, especially in areas directly bordering the city centre, such as [Frederik Hendrikbuurt](/wiki/Frederik_Hendrikbuurt "Frederik Hendrikbuurt"). This urban renewal and expansion of the traditional centre of the city---with the construction of artificial islands of the new eastern [IJburg](/wiki/IJburg "IJburg") neighbourhood---is part of the Structural Vision Amsterdam 2040 initiative.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Amsterdam_Photo_2020_Copernicus_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_Photo_2020_Copernicus_Sentinel-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Photo_2020_Copernicus_Sentinel-2.jpg) Satellite photo of Amsterdam, 2020 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Gem-Amsterdam-OpenTopo.jpg/220px-Gem-Amsterdam-OpenTopo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gem-Amsterdam-OpenTopo.jpg) Topographic map of Amsterdam [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Amsterdam-centrum-OpenTopo.jpg/220px-Amsterdam-centrum-OpenTopo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam-centrum-OpenTopo.jpg) Large-scale map of the city centre of Amsterdam, including sightseeing markers, as of April 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit)^.

Amsterdam is located in the Western Netherlands, in the province of [North Holland](/wiki/North_Holland "North Holland"), the capital of which is not Amsterdam, but rather [Haarlem](/wiki/Haarlem "Haarlem"). The river [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel") ends in the city centre and connects to a large number of canals that eventually terminate in the [IJ](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)"). Amsterdam's elevation is about −2 m (−6.6 ft) [below sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level").^[\[79\]](#cite_note-elevation-80)^ The surrounding land is flat as it is formed of large [polders](/wiki/Polder "Polder"). An artificial forest, [Amsterdamse Bos](/wiki/Amsterdamse_Bos "Amsterdamse Bos"), is in the southwest. Amsterdam is connected to the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") through the long [North Sea Canal](/wiki/North_Sea_Canal "North Sea Canal").{#cite_ref-elevation_80-0}

Amsterdam is intensely urbanised, as is the [Amsterdam metropolitan area](/wiki/Amsterdam_metropolitan_area "Amsterdam metropolitan area") surrounding the city. Comprising 219.4 km^2^ (84.7 sq mi) of land, the [city proper](/wiki/City_limits "City limits") has 4,457 inhabitants per km^2^ and 2,275 houses per km^2^.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-density-81)^ Parks and [nature reserves](/wiki/Nature_reserve "Nature reserve") make up 12% of Amsterdam's land area.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-12percent-82)^{#cite_ref-12percent_82-0}  

### Water {#Water}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Water")\]

Amsterdam has more than 100 km (60 mi) of [canals](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), most of which are navigable by boat. The city's three main canals are the [Prinsengracht](/wiki/Prinsengracht "Prinsengracht"), the [Herengracht](/wiki/Herengracht "Herengracht"), and the [Keizersgracht](/wiki/Keizersgracht "Keizersgracht").

In the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), Amsterdam was surrounded by a moat, called the [Singel](/wiki/Singel "Singel"), which now forms the innermost ring in the city, and gives the city centre a horseshoe shape. The city is also served by a [seaport](/wiki/Port_of_Amsterdam "Port of Amsterdam"). It has been compared with [Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice"), due to its division into about 90 islands, which are linked by more than 1,200 bridges.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-83)^{#cite_ref-83}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Nieuwendammerdijk%2C_Amsterdam%2C_North_Holland%2C_Netherlands_-_panoramio_%283%29.jpg/220px-Nieuwendammerdijk%2C_Amsterdam%2C_North_Holland%2C_Netherlands_-_panoramio_%283%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nieuwendammerdijk,_Amsterdam,_North_Holland,_Netherlands_-_panoramio_(3).jpg) [Nieuwendammerdijk en Buiksloterdijk](/wiki/Nieuwendammerdijk_en_Buiksloterdijk "Nieuwendammerdijk en Buiksloterdijk"), [Amsterdam-Noord](/wiki/Amsterdam-Noord "Amsterdam-Noord"), winter 2010

Amsterdam has an [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Cfb* )^[\[83\]](#cite_note-Weatherbase-84)^ strongly influenced by its proximity to the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") to the west, with prevailing westerly winds.{#cite_ref-Weatherbase_84-0}

Amsterdam, as well as most of the North Holland province, lies in [USDA](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture "United States Department of Agriculture") [Hardiness zone](/wiki/Hardiness_zone "Hardiness zone") 8b. Frosts mainly occur during spells of easterly or northeasterly winds from the inner European continent. Even then, because Amsterdam is surrounded on three sides by large bodies of water, as well as having a significant [heat-island effect](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island"), nights rarely fall below −5 °C (23 °F), while it could easily be −12 °C (10 °F) in [Hilversum](/wiki/Hilversum "Hilversum"), 25 km (16 mi) southeast.

Summers are moderately warm with several hot and humid days with occasional rain every month. The average daily high in August is 22.1 °C (72 °F), and 30 °C (86 °F) or higher is only measured on average on 2.5 days, placing Amsterdam in AHS Heat Zone 2. The record extremes range from −19.7 °C (−3.5 °F) to 36.3 °C (97.3 °F).^[\[84\]](#cite_note-85)^^[\[85\]](#cite_note-Extreme_temps-86)^^\[*[unreliable source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Reliable sources")*\]^ Days with more than 1 mm (0.04 in) of [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation "Precipitation") are common, on average 133 days per year.{#cite_ref-Extreme_temps_86-0}

Amsterdam's average annual precipitation is 838 mm (33 in).^[\[86\]](#cite_note-87)^ A large part of this precipitation falls as light rain or brief showers. Cloudy and damp days are common during the cooler months of October through March.{#cite_ref-87}

In 1300, Amsterdam's population was around 1,000 people.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-:0-92)^ While many towns in Holland experienced population decline during the 15th and 16th centuries, Amsterdam's population grew,^[\[92\]](#cite_note-:1-93)^ mainly due to the rise of the profitable [Baltic maritime trade](/wiki/Baltic_maritime_trade_(c._1400%E2%80%931800) "Baltic maritime trade (c. 1400–1800)") especially in grain after the Burgundian victory in the [Dutch--Hanseatic War](/wiki/Dutch%E2%80%93Hanseatic_War "Dutch–Hanseatic War") in 1441.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-94)^ The population of Amsterdam was only modest compared to the towns and cities of [Flanders](/wiki/County_of_Flanders "County of Flanders") and [Brabant](/wiki/Duchy_of_Brabant "Duchy of Brabant"), which comprised the most urbanized area of the Low Countries.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}

This changed when, during the [Dutch Revolt](/wiki/Dutch_Revolt "Dutch Revolt"), many people from the Southern Netherlands fled to the North, especially after [Antwerp fell to Spanish forces](/wiki/Fall_of_Antwerp "Fall of Antwerp") in 1585. Jews from Spain, Portugal, and Eastern Europe similarly settled in Amsterdam, as did Germans and Scandinavians.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-:1-93)^ In thirty years, Amsterdam's population more than doubled between 1585 and 1610.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-96)^ By 1600, its population was around 50,000.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-:0-92)^ During the 1660s, Amsterdam's population reached 200,000.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-97)^ The city's growth levelled off and the population stabilized around 240,000 for most of the 18th century.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}

In 1750, Amsterdam was the [fourth largest city in Western Europe](/wiki/List_of_largest_European_cities_in_history "List of largest European cities in history"), behind London (676,000), Paris (560,000) and Naples (324,000).^[\[98\]](#cite_note-99)^ This was all the more remarkable as Amsterdam was neither the capital city nor the seat of government of the [Dutch Republic](/wiki/Dutch_Republic "Dutch Republic"), which itself was a much smaller state than Great Britain, France or the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"). In contrast to those other metropolises, Amsterdam was also surrounded by large towns such as [Leiden](/wiki/Leiden "Leiden") (about 67,000), [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam") (45,000), [Haarlem](/wiki/Haarlem "Haarlem") (38,000), and [Utrecht](/wiki/Utrecht "Utrecht") (30,000).^[\[99\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrijhoffPrak20059-100)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrijhoffPrak20059_100-0}

The city's population declined in the early 19th century,^[\[100\]](#cite_note-101)^ dipping under 200,000 in 1820.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-102)^ By the second half of the 19th century, industrialization spurred renewed growth.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-103)^ Amsterdam's population hit an all-time high of 872,000 in 1959,^[\[103\]](#cite_note-104)^ before declining in the following decades due to government-sponsored suburbanisation to so-called *groeikernen* (growth centres) such as [Purmerend](/wiki/Purmerend "Purmerend") and [Almere](/wiki/Almere "Almere").^[\[104\]](#cite_note-105)^^[\[105\]](#cite_note-106)^^[\[106\]](#cite_note-:2-107)^ Between 1970 and 1980, Amsterdam experienced a sharp population decline, peaking at a net loss of 25,000 people in 1973.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-:2-107)^ By 1985 the city had only 675,570 residents.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-108)^ This was soon followed by [reurbanization](/wiki/Reurbanization "Reurbanization") and [gentrification](/wiki/Gentrification "Gentrification"),^[\[108\]](#cite_note-109)^^[\[106\]](#cite_note-:2-107)^ leading to renewed population growth in the 2010s. Also in the 2010s, much of Amsterdam's population growth was due to immigration to the city.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-110)^{#cite_ref-110}  

### Diversity and immigration {#Diversity_and_immigration}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Diversity and immigration")\]

In the 16th and 17th centuries, non-Dutch immigrants to Amsterdam were mostly Protestant [Huguenots](/wiki/Huguenot "Huguenot") and [Flemings](/wiki/Flemish_people "Flemish people"), [Sephardic Jews](/wiki/Sephardic_Jews "Sephardic Jews"), and [Westphalians](/wiki/Westphalia "Westphalia"). Huguenots came after the [Edict of Fontainebleau](/wiki/Edict_of_Fontainebleau "Edict of Fontainebleau") in 1685, while the Flemish Protestants came during the [Eighty Years' War](/wiki/Eighty_Years%27_War "Eighty Years' War") against Catholic Spain. The Westphalians came to Amsterdam mostly for economic reasons; their influx continued through the 18th and 19th centuries.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Before the Second World War, 10% of the city population was [Jewish](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Amsterdam "History of the Jews in Amsterdam"). Just twenty percent of them survived the [Holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust "Holocaust").^[\[110\]](#cite_note-111)^{#cite_ref-111}

Amsterdam experienced an influx of religions and cultures after the Second World War. With 180 different nationalities,^[\[111\]](#cite_note-112)^ Amsterdam is home to one of the widest varieties of nationalities of any city in the world.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-113)^ The proportion of the population of immigrant origin in the city proper is about 50%^[\[113\]](#cite_note-114)^ and 88% of the population are Dutch citizens.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}

The first mass immigration in the 20th century was by people from Indonesia, who came to Amsterdam after the independence of the [Dutch East Indies](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies "Dutch East Indies") in the 1940s and 1950s. In the 1960s [guest workers](/wiki/Foreign_worker "Foreign worker") from Turkey, Morocco, Italy, and Spain immigrated to Amsterdam. After the independence of Suriname in 1975, a large wave of Surinamese settled in Amsterdam, mostly in the [Bijlmer](/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer") area. Other immigrants, including refugees [asylum seekers](/wiki/Right_of_asylum "Right of asylum") and [undocumented immigrants](/wiki/Illegal_immigration "Illegal immigration"), came from Europe, the Americas, Asia, and Africa. In the 1970s and 1980s, many 'old' Amsterdammers moved to 'new' cities like [Almere](/wiki/Almere "Almere") and [Purmerend](/wiki/Purmerend "Purmerend"), prompted by the third [Land-use planning](/wiki/Land-use_planning "Land-use planning") bill of the Dutch Government. This bill promoted suburbanization and arranged for new developments in so-called "groeikernen", literally *cores of growth* . Young professionals and artists moved into neighborhoods [De Pijp](/wiki/De_Pijp "De Pijp") and the [Jordaan](/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") abandoned by these Amsterdammers. The non-Western immigrants settled mostly in the [social housing](/wiki/Public_housing "Public housing") projects in Amsterdam-West and the Bijlmer. Today, people of non-Western origin make up approximately one-fifth of the population of Amsterdam, and more than 30% of the city's children.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-116)^^[\[116\]](#cite_note-OS_4351-117)^^[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)^ A slight majority of the residents of Amsterdam have at least one parent who was born outside the country. However, a much larger majority has at least one parent who was born inside the country (intercultural marriages are common in the city). Only a third of inhabitants under 15 are *[autochthons](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples "Indigenous peoples") (* person with two parents of [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") origin).^[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)^^[\[119\]](#cite_note-:10-120)^ In 2023, *[autochthons](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples "Indigenous peoples")* were a minority in 40% of Amsterdam's neighborhoods.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-:10-120)^ Segregation along ethnic lines is visible, with people of non-Western origin, considered a separate group by [Statistics Netherlands](/wiki/Statistics_Netherlands "Statistics Netherlands"), concentrating in specific neighborhoods especially in [Nieuw-West](/wiki/Amsterdam_Nieuw-West "Amsterdam Nieuw-West"), [Zeeburg](/wiki/Zeeburg "Zeeburg"), [Bijlmer](/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer") and in certain areas of [Amsterdam-Noord](/wiki/Amsterdam-Noord "Amsterdam-Noord").^[\[120\]](#cite_note-121)^^[\[121\]](#cite_note-122)^{#cite_ref-122}

In 2000, Christians formed the largest [religious group](/wiki/Religious_denomination "Religious denomination") in the city (28% of the population). The next largest religion was Islam (8%), most of whose followers were [Sunni](/wiki/Sunni_Islam "Sunni Islam").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-religion-124)^^[\[124\]](#cite_note-125)^ In 2015, Christians formed the largest [religious group](/wiki/Religious_denomination "Religious denomination") in the city (28% of the population). The next largest religion was Islam (7.1%), most of whose followers were [Sunni](/wiki/Sunni_Islam "Sunni Islam").^[\[122\]](#cite_note-auto-123)^{#cite_ref-auto_123-1}

Amsterdam has been one of the municipalities in the Netherlands that provided immigrants with extensive and free [Dutch-language](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language") courses, which have benefited many immigrants.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Religion")\]
