In 1578, the largely Catholic city of Amsterdam joined the revolt against Spanish rule,^[\[127\]](#cite_note-:3-128)^ late in comparison to other major northern Dutch cities.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-:4-129)^ Catholic priests were driven out of the city.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-:3-128)^ Following the Dutch takeover, all churches were converted to Protestant worship.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-130)^ [Calvinism](/wiki/Calvinism "Calvinism") was declared the main religion.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-:4-129)^ It was forbidden to openly profess [Roman Catholicism](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism "Roman Catholicism") and the [Catholic hierarchy was prohibited until the mid-19th century](/wiki/Reestablishment_of_the_episcopal_hierarchy_in_the_Netherlands "Reestablishment of the episcopal hierarchy in the Netherlands"). This led to the establishment of [clandestine churches](/wiki/Clandestine_church "Clandestine church"), covert religious buildings hidden in pre-existing buildings. Catholics, some Jews, and dissenting Protestants worshipped in such buildings.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-131)^ A large influx of foreigners of many religions came to 17th-century Amsterdam, in particular [Sefardic Jews](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") from Spain and Portugal,^[\[131\]](#cite_note-132)^^[\[132\]](#cite_note-133)^ [Huguenots](/wiki/Huguenot "Huguenot") from France,^[\[133\]](#cite_note-134)^ [Lutherans](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism"), [Mennonites](/wiki/Mennonites "Mennonites"), as well as Protestants from across the Netherlands.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-135)^ This led to the establishment of many non-Dutch-speaking churches.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ In 1603, the Jewish received permission to practice their religion in the city. In 1639, the first synagogue was consecrated.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-136)^ The Jews came to call the town "[Jerusalem of the West](/wiki/Jerusalem_of_the_West "Jerusalem of the West")".^[\[136\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}

As they became established in the city, other [Christian denominations](/wiki/Christian_denominations "Christian denominations") used converted Catholic chapels to conduct their own services. The oldest English-language church congregation in the world outside the United Kingdom is found at the [Begijnhof](/wiki/Begijnhof,_Amsterdam "Begijnhof, Amsterdam").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^^[\[137\]](#cite_note-138)^ Regular services there are still offered in English under the auspices of the [Church of Scotland](/wiki/Church_of_Scotland "Church of Scotland").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-englishchurch-139)^ Being Calvinists, the Huguenots soon integrated into the [Dutch Reformed Church](/wiki/Dutch_Reformed_Church "Dutch Reformed Church"), though often retaining their own congregations. Some, commonly referred to by the moniker 'Walloon', are recognizable today as they offer occasional services in French.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-englishchurch_139-0}

In the second half of the 17th century, Amsterdam experienced an influx of [Ashkenazim](/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews "Ashkenazi Jews"), Jews from [Central and Eastern Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe"). Jews often fled the [pogroms](/wiki/Pogrom "Pogrom") in those areas. The first Ashkenazis who arrived in Amsterdam were [refugees](/wiki/Refugee "Refugee") from the [Khmelnytsky uprising](/wiki/Khmelnytsky_uprising "Khmelnytsky uprising") occurring in Ukraine and the [Thirty Years' War](/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War "Thirty Years' War"), which devastated much of Central Europe. They not only founded their own synagogues but had a strong influence on the 'Amsterdam dialect' adding a large [Yiddish](/wiki/Yiddish_language "Yiddish language") local vocabulary.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-:5-140)^ Despite an absence of an official Jewish [ghetto](/wiki/Ghetto "Ghetto"), most Jews preferred to live in the eastern part, which used to be the centre of medieval Amsterdam. The main street of this Jewish neighbourhood was Jodenbreestraat. The neighbourhood comprised the [Waterlooplein](/wiki/Waterlooplein "Waterlooplein") and the [Nieuwmarkt](/wiki/Nieuwmarkt "Nieuwmarkt").^[\[139\]](#cite_note-:5-140)^^[\[140\]](#cite_note-Jodenbuurt_Amsterdam-141)^ Buildings in this neighbourhood fell into disrepair after the Second World War^[\[141\]](#cite_note-142)^ a large section of the neighbourhood was demolished during the construction of the metro system. This led to riots, and as a result, the original plans for large-scale reconstruction were abandoned by the government.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-143)^^[\[143\]](#cite_note-144)^ The neighbourhood was rebuilt with smaller-scale residence buildings based on its original layout.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Westerkerk_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-Westerkerk_Amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Westerkerk_Amsterdam.jpg) The [Westerkerk](/wiki/Westerkerk "Westerkerk") in the Centrum borough, one of Amsterdam's best-known churches

Catholic churches in Amsterdam have been constructed since the restoration of the episcopal hierarchy in 1853.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-146)^ One of the principal architects behind the city's Catholic churches, [Cuypers](/wiki/Pierre_Cuypers "Pierre Cuypers"), was also responsible for the Amsterdam Centraal station and the [Rijksmuseum](/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum").^[\[146\]](#cite_note-147)^^[\[147\]](#cite_note-148)^{#cite_ref-148}

In 1924, the [Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") hosted the [International Eucharistic Congress](/wiki/Eucharistic_congress "Eucharistic congress") in Amsterdam;^[\[148\]](#cite_note-149)^ numerous Catholic [prelates](/wiki/Prelate "Prelate") visited the city, where festivities were held in churches and stadiums.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-150)^ Catholic processions on the public streets, however, were still forbidden under law at the time.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-151)^ Only in the 20th century was Amsterdam's relation to Catholicism normalised,^[\[151\]](#cite_note-152)^ but despite its far larger population size, the episcopal see of the city was placed in the provincial town of [Haarlem](/wiki/Haarlem "Haarlem").^[\[152\]](#cite_note-Diocese_of_Haarlem-153)^{#cite_ref-Diocese_of_Haarlem_153-0}

Historically, Amsterdam has been predominantly Christian. In 1900 Christians formed the largest [religious group](/wiki/Religious_denomination "Religious denomination") in the city (70% of the population), [Dutch Reformed Church](/wiki/Dutch_Reformed_Church "Dutch Reformed Church") formed 45% of the city population, and the Catholic Church formed 25% of the city population.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-154)^ In recent times, religious demographics in Amsterdam have been changed by immigration from former colonies. [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") has been introduced from the Hindu diaspora from Suriname^[\[154\]](#cite_note-155)^ and several distinct branches of Islam have been brought from various parts of the world.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-156)^ Islam is now the largest non-Christian religion in Amsterdam.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-random-127)^ The large community of Ghanaian immigrants has established African churches,^[\[156\]](#cite_note-157)^ often in parking garages in the [Bijlmer](/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer") area.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}  

Cityscape and architecture {#Cityscape_and_architecture}
--------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Cityscape and architecture")\]  
See also: [List of tallest buildings in Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Amsterdam "List of tallest buildings in Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Amsterdam_Cityscape.jpg/800px-Amsterdam_Cityscape.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Cityscape.jpg) View of the city centre looking southwest from the Oosterdokskade [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/View_of_Amsterdam.JPG/330px-View_of_Amsterdam.JPG)](/wiki/File:View_of_Amsterdam.JPG) A 1538 painting by [Cornelis Anthonisz](/wiki/Cornelis_Anthonisz "Cornelis Anthonisz") showing a bird's-eye view of Amsterdam. The famous [Grachtengordel](/wiki/Grachtengordel "Grachtengordel") had not yet been established.

Amsterdam fans out south from the [Amsterdam Centraal station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_station "Amsterdam Centraal station") and [Damrak](/wiki/Damrak "Damrak"), the main street off the station. The oldest area of the town is known as [De Wallen](/wiki/De_Wallen "De Wallen") (English: "The Quays"). It lies to the east of Damrak and contains the city's famous red-light district. To the south of De Wallen is the old Jewish quarter of Waterlooplein.

The medieval and colonial age [canals of Amsterdam](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), known as *grachten* , embraces the heart of the city where homes have interesting gables. Beyond the Grachtengordel are the former working-class areas of [Jordaan](/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") and de Pijp. The [Museumplein](/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") with the city's major museums, the [Vondelpark](/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark"), a 19th-century park named after the Dutch writer [Joost van den Vondel](/wiki/Joost_van_den_Vondel "Joost van den Vondel"), as well as the [Plantage](/wiki/Plantage_(Amsterdam) "Plantage (Amsterdam)") neighbourhood, with the [zoo](/wiki/Natura_Artis_Magistra "Natura Artis Magistra"), are also located outside the Grachtengordel.

Several parts of the city and the surrounding urban area are [polders](/wiki/Polder "Polder"). This can be recognised by the suffix *-meer* which means *lake* , as in [Aalsmeer](/wiki/Aalsmeer "Aalsmeer"), [Bijlmermeer](/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer"), [Haarlemmermeer](/wiki/Haarlemmermeer "Haarlemmermeer") and [Watergraafsmeer](/wiki/Watergraafsmeer "Watergraafsmeer").  

### Canals {#Canals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Canals")\]  
Main article: [Canals of Amsterdam](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Town_Houses_on_Canal_in_Amsterdam_-_Nov_1977.jpg/220px-Town_Houses_on_Canal_in_Amsterdam_-_Nov_1977.jpg)](/wiki/File:Town_Houses_on_Canal_in_Amsterdam_-_Nov_1977.jpg) Rokin -- November 1977

The Amsterdam canal system is the result of conscious [city planning](/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning").^[\[158\]](#cite_note-canals-159)^ In the early 17th century, when immigration was at a peak, a comprehensive plan was developed that was based on four concentric half-circles of canals with their ends emerging at the [IJ](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") bay. Known as the [Grachtengordel](/wiki/Grachtengordel "Grachtengordel"), three of the canals were mostly for residential development: the [Herengracht](/wiki/Herengracht "Herengracht") (where "Heren" refers to *Heren Regeerders van de stad Amsterdam* , ruling lords of Amsterdam, while *[gracht](/wiki/Gracht "Gracht")* means canal, so that the name can be roughly translated as "Canal of the Lords"), [Keizersgracht](/wiki/Keizersgracht "Keizersgracht") (Emperor's Canal) and [Prinsengracht](/wiki/Prinsengracht "Prinsengracht") (Prince's Canal).^[\[159\]](#cite_note-160)^ The fourth and outermost canal is the [Singelgracht](/wiki/Singelgracht "Singelgracht"), which is often not mentioned on maps because it is a collective name for all canals in the outer ring. The Singelgracht should not be confused with the oldest and innermost canal, the [Singel](/wiki/Singel "Singel").{#cite_ref-160}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Herengracht-december-2.jpg/220px-Herengracht-december-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Herengracht-december-2.jpg) Herengracht [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Prinsengracht_towads_Lekkeresluis_from_Bridge_Prinsenstraat_2016-09-12.jpg/220px-Prinsengracht_towads_Lekkeresluis_from_Bridge_Prinsenstraat_2016-09-12.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prinsengracht_towads_Lekkeresluis_from_Bridge_Prinsenstraat_2016-09-12.jpg) Prinsengracht

The canals served for defense, [water management](/wiki/Water_resource_management "Water resource management") and transport. The defenses took the form of a moat and [earthen dikes](/wiki/Earthworks_(engineering) "Earthworks (engineering)"), with gates at transit points, but otherwise no masonry [superstructures](/wiki/Superstructure "Superstructure").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-161)^ The original plans have been lost, so historians, such as Ed Taverne, need to speculate on the original intentions: it is thought that the considerations of the layout were purely practical and defensive rather than ornamental.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-162)^{#cite_ref-162}

Construction started in 1613 and proceeded from west to east, across the breadth of the layout, like a gigantic [windshield wiper](/wiki/Windscreen_wiper "Windscreen wiper") as the historian [Geert Mak](/wiki/Geert_Mak "Geert Mak") calls it -- and not from the centre outwards, as a popular myth has it. The canal construction in the southern sector was completed by 1656. Subsequently, the construction of residential buildings proceeded slowly. The eastern part of the concentric canal plan, covering the area between the Amstel River and the IJ Bay, has never been implemented. In the following centuries, the land was used for parks, senior citizens' homes, theatres, other public facilities, and waterways without much planning.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-163)^ Over the years, several canals have been filled in, becoming streets or squares, such as the [Nieuwezijds Voorburgwal](/wiki/Nieuwezijds_Voorburgwal "Nieuwezijds Voorburgwal") and the [Spui](/wiki/Spui_(Amsterdam) "Spui (Amsterdam)").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-filledincanals-164)^{#cite_ref-filledincanals_164-0}  

### Expansion {#Expansion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Expansion")\]  
Main article: [Expansion of Amsterdam since the 19th century](/wiki/Expansion_of_Amsterdam_since_the_19th_century "Expansion of Amsterdam since the 19th century")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Brug_127_in_de_Lijnbaansgracht_over_de_Egelantiersgracht_foto_4.jpg/220px-Brug_127_in_de_Lijnbaansgracht_over_de_Egelantiersgracht_foto_4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Brug_127_in_de_Lijnbaansgracht_over_de_Egelantiersgracht_foto_4.jpg) The [Egelantiersgracht](/wiki/Egelantiersgracht "Egelantiersgracht") lies west of the [Grachtengordel](/wiki/Grachtengordel "Grachtengordel"), in the [Jordaan](/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") neighbourhood.

After the development of Amsterdam's canals in the 17th century, the city did not grow beyond its borders for two centuries. During the 19th century, [Samuel Sarphati](/wiki/Samuel_Sarphati "Samuel Sarphati") devised a plan based on the grandeur of Paris and London at that time. The plan envisaged the construction of new houses, public buildings, and streets just outside the [Grachtengordel](/wiki/Grachtengordel_(Amsterdam) "Grachtengordel (Amsterdam)"). The main aim of the plan, however, was to improve public health. Although the plan did not expand the city, it did produce some of the largest public buildings to date, like the *Paleis voor Volksvlijt* .^[\[164\]](#cite_note-joodsmuseum-165)^^[\[165\]](#cite_note-zgsarphati-166)^^[\[166\]](#cite_note-jlgsarphati-167)^{#cite_ref-jlgsarphati_167-0}

Following Sarphati, civil engineers Jacobus van Niftrik and Jan Kalff designed an entire ring of 19th-century neighbourhoods surrounding the city's centre, with the city preserving the ownership of all land outside the 17th-century limit, thus firmly controlling development.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-168)^ Most of these neighbourhoods became home to the working class.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-oudzuid-169)^{#cite_ref-oudzuid_169-0}

In response to overcrowding, two plans were designed at the beginning of the 20th century which were very different from anything Amsterdam had ever seen before: *Plan Zuid* (designed by the architect [Berlage](/wiki/Hendrik_Petrus_Berlage "Hendrik Petrus Berlage")) and *West* . These plans involved the development of new neighbourhoods consisting of housing blocks for all social classes.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-archiefberlage-170)^^[\[170\]](#cite_note-bmzberlage-171)^{#cite_ref-bmzberlage_171-0}

After the Second World War, large new neighbourhoods were built in the western, southeastern, and northern parts of the city. These new neighbourhoods were built to relieve the city's shortage of living space and give people affordable houses with modern conveniences. The neighbourhoods consisted mainly of large housing blocks located among green spaces, connected to wide roads, making the neighbourhoods easily accessible by [motor car](/wiki/Car "Car"). The western suburbs which were built in that period are collectively called the Westelijke Tuinsteden. The area to the southeast of the city built during the same period is known as the [Bijlmer](/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer").^[\[171\]](#cite_note-bijlmer-172)^^[\[172\]](#cite_note-westelijketuinsteden-173)^{#cite_ref-westelijketuinsteden_173-0}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Architecture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Palacio_Real%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_07-09_HDR.jpg/220px-Palacio_Real%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_07-09_HDR.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palacio_Real,_%C3%81msterdam,_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos,_2016-05-30,_DD_07-09_HDR.jpg) The [Royal Palace of Amsterdam](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam"), by architects [Jacob van Campen](/wiki/Jacob_van_Campen "Jacob van Campen") and [Daniël Stalpaert](/wiki/Dani%C3%ABl_Stalpaert "Daniël Stalpaert") is characteristic of the architecture of the [Dutch Baroque architecture](/wiki/Dutch_Baroque_architecture "Dutch Baroque architecture").

Amsterdam has a rich [architectural history](/wiki/History_of_architecture "History of architecture"). The oldest building in Amsterdam is the [Oude Kerk](/wiki/Oude_Kerk,_Amsterdam "Oude Kerk, Amsterdam") (English: Old Church), at the heart of the Wallen, consecrated in 1306.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-Oude_Kerk-174)^ The oldest wooden building is *Het Houten Huys* ^[\[174\]](#cite_note-houtenhuys-175)^ at the [Begijnhof](/wiki/Begijnhof,_Amsterdam "Begijnhof, Amsterdam"). It was constructed around 1425 and is one of only two existing wooden buildings. It is also one of the few examples of [Gothic architecture](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture") in Amsterdam. The oldest stone building in the Netherlands, The Moriaan is built in ['s-Hertogenbosch](/wiki/%27s-Hertogenbosch "'s-Hertogenbosch").{#cite_ref-houtenhuys_175-0}

In the 16th century, wooden buildings were razed and replaced with brick ones. During this period, many buildings were constructed in the [architectural style](/wiki/Architectural_style "Architectural style") of the [Renaissance](/wiki/The_Renaissance "The Renaissance"). Buildings of this period are very recognisable with their [stepped gable](/wiki/Crow-stepped_gable "Crow-stepped gable") façades, which is the common Dutch Renaissance style. Amsterdam quickly developed its own [Renaissance architecture](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture"). These buildings were built according to the principles of the architect [Hendrick de Keyser](/wiki/Hendrick_de_Keyser "Hendrick de Keyser").^[\[175\]](#cite_note-dekeyser-176)^ One of the most striking buildings designed by Hendrick de Keyser is the [Westerkerk](/wiki/Westerkerk "Westerkerk"). In the 17th century [baroque architecture](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") became very popular, as it was elsewhere in Europe. This roughly coincided with Amsterdam's [Golden Age](/wiki/Dutch_Golden_Age "Dutch Golden Age"). The leading architects of this style in Amsterdam were [Jacob van Campen](/wiki/Jacob_van_Campen "Jacob van Campen"), [Philips Vingboons](/wiki/Philips_Vingboons "Philips Vingboons") and [Daniel Stalpaert](/wiki/Dani%C3%ABl_Stalpaert "Daniël Stalpaert").^[\[176\]](#cite_note-holclass-177)^{#cite_ref-holclass_177-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Amsterdam_%28NL%29%2C_Begijnhof_--_2015_--_7215-8.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_%28NL%29%2C_Begijnhof_--_2015_--_7215-8.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_(NL),_Begijnhof_--_2015_--_7215-8.jpg) The [Begijnhof](/wiki/Begijnhof,_Amsterdam "Begijnhof, Amsterdam") is one of the oldest [hofjes](/wiki/Hofje "Hofje") in Amsterdam. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/%C3%96ffentliche_Bibliothek_und_Konservatorium_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-%C3%96ffentliche_Bibliothek_und_Konservatorium_Amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C3%96ffentliche_Bibliothek_und_Konservatorium_Amsterdam.jpg) The [Openbare Bibliotheek Amsterdam](/wiki/Openbare_Bibliotheek_Amsterdam "Openbare Bibliotheek Amsterdam") and [Conservatorium van Amsterdam](/wiki/Conservatorium_van_Amsterdam "Conservatorium van Amsterdam"), two examples of 21st-century architecture in the centre of the city

Philip Vingboons designed splendid merchants' houses throughout the city. A famous building in [baroque style](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") in Amsterdam is the [Royal Palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam") on [Dam Square](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"). Throughout the 18th century, Amsterdam was heavily influenced by [French culture](/wiki/Culture_of_France "Culture of France"). This is reflected in the architecture of that period. Around 1815, architects broke with the baroque style and started building in different neo-styles.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-neostijl-178)^ Most Gothic style buildings date from that era and are therefore said to be built in a [neo-gothic](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture") style. At the end of the 19th century, the [Jugendstil](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") or [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") style became popular and many new buildings were constructed in this architectural style. Since Amsterdam expanded rapidly during this period, new buildings adjacent to the city centre were also built in this style. The houses in the vicinity of the [Museum Square](/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") in Amsterdam Oud-Zuid are an example of Jugendstil. The last style that was popular in Amsterdam before the [modern era](/wiki/Modern_history "Modern history") was [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco"). Amsterdam had its own version of the style, which was called the [Amsterdamse School](/wiki/Amsterdam_School "Amsterdam School"). Whole districts were built in this style, such as the *Rivierenbuurt* .^[\[178\]](#cite_note-aschool-179)^ A notable feature of the façades of buildings designed in Amsterdamse School is that they are highly decorated and ornate, with oddly shaped windows and doors.{#cite_ref-aschool_179-0}

The old city centre is the focal point of all the architectural styles before the end of the 19th century. Jugendstil and Georgian are mostly found outside the city centre in the neighbourhoods built in the early 20th century, although there are also some striking examples of these styles in the city centre. Most historic buildings in the city centre and nearby are houses, such as the famous merchants' houses lining the canals.  

### Parks and recreational areas {#Parks_and_recreational_areas}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Parks and recreational areas")\]  
Main articles: [List of parks in Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_parks_in_Amsterdam "List of parks in Amsterdam") and [List of squares in Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_squares_in_Amsterdam "List of squares in Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Amsterdam_map_indicating_parks_-_01.png/220px-Amsterdam_map_indicating_parks_-_01.png)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_map_indicating_parks_-_01.png)  
* A: [Vondelpark](/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark")
* B: [Beatrixpark](/wiki/Beatrixpark "Beatrixpark")
* C: [Sarphatipark](/wiki/Sarphatipark "Sarphatipark")
* D: [Oosterpark](/wiki/Oosterpark_(Amsterdam) "Oosterpark (Amsterdam)")
* E: [Park Frankendael](/w/index.php?title=Park_Frankendael&action=edit&redlink=1 "Park Frankendael (page does not exist)")
* F: [Rembrandtpark](/wiki/Rembrandtpark "Rembrandtpark")
* G: [Westerpark](/wiki/Westerpark_(park) "Westerpark (park)")
* H: [Flevopark](/wiki/Flevopark "Flevopark")
* I: [Amsterdamse Bos](/wiki/Amsterdamse_Bos "Amsterdamse Bos")
* J: [Amstelpark](/wiki/Amstelpark "Amstelpark")
* K: [Hortus Botanicus](/wiki/Hortus_Botanicus_(Amsterdam) "Hortus Botanicus (Amsterdam)")
* L: [Wertheimerpark](/w/index.php?title=Wertheimerpark&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wertheimerpark (page does not exist)")
* M: [Martin Luther Kingpark](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther_Kingpark&action=edit&redlink=1 "Martin Luther Kingpark (page does not exist)")
* N: [Sloterpark](/wiki/Sloterpark "Sloterpark")

Amsterdam has many parks, open spaces, and squares throughout the city. The [Vondelpark](/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark"), the largest park in the city, is located in the [Oud-Zuid](/wiki/Amsterdam_Oud-Zuid "Amsterdam Oud-Zuid") neighbourhood and is named after the 17th-century Amsterdam author [Joost van den Vondel](/wiki/Joost_van_den_Vondel "Joost van den Vondel"). Yearly, the park has around 10 million visitors. In the park is an open-air theatre, a playground, and several [horeca](/wiki/Horeca "Horeca") facilities. In the [Zuid](/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuid "Amsterdam-Zuid") borough, is the Beatrixpark, named after [Queen Beatrix](/wiki/Beatrix_of_the_Netherlands "Beatrix of the Netherlands"). Between Amsterdam and [Amstelveen](/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen") is the [Amsterdamse Bos](/wiki/Amsterdamse_Bos "Amsterdamse Bos") ("Amsterdam Forest"), the largest recreational area in Amsterdam. Annually, almost 4.5 million people visit the park, which has a size of 1,000 hectares (2,500 acres) and is approximately three times the size of [Central Park](/wiki/Central_Park "Central Park").^[\[179\]](#cite_note-180)^ The [Amstelpark](/wiki/Amstelpark "Amstelpark") in the [Zuid](/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuid "Amsterdam-Zuid") borough houses the Rieker windmill, which dates to 1636. Other parks include the [Sarphatipark](/wiki/Sarphatipark "Sarphatipark") in the [De Pijp](/wiki/De_Pijp "De Pijp") neighbourhood, the [Oosterpark](/wiki/Oosterpark_(Amsterdam) "Oosterpark (Amsterdam)") in the [Oost](/wiki/Amsterdam-Oost "Amsterdam-Oost") borough and the [Westerpark](/wiki/Westerpark_(park) "Westerpark (park)") in the [Westerpark](/wiki/Westerpark_(neighbourhood) "Westerpark (neighbourhood)") neighbourhood. The city has three beaches: Nemo Beach, Citybeach "Het stenen hoofd" (Silodam), and Blijburg, all located in the Centrum borough.{#cite_ref-180}

The city has many open squares (*plein* in Dutch). The namesake of the city as the site of the original dam, [Dam Square](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"), is the main city square and has the [Royal Palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam") and [National Monument](/wiki/National_Monument_(Amsterdam) "National Monument (Amsterdam)"). [Museumplein](/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") hosts various museums, including the [Rijksmuseum](/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum"), [Van Gogh Museum](/wiki/Van_Gogh_Museum "Van Gogh Museum"), and [Stedelijk Museum](/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam"). Other squares include [Rembrandtplein](/wiki/Rembrandtplein "Rembrandtplein"), [Muntplein](/wiki/Muntplein,_Amsterdam "Muntplein, Amsterdam"), [Nieuwmarkt](/wiki/Nieuwmarkt "Nieuwmarkt"), [Leidseplein](/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein"), [Spui](/wiki/Spui_(Amsterdam) "Spui (Amsterdam)") and [Waterlooplein](/wiki/Waterlooplein "Waterlooplein"). Also, near Amsterdam is the [Nekkeveld estate](/wiki/Nekkeveld_estate "Nekkeveld estate") conservation project.  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Beursplein_5_%28cropped_and_edited%29.jpg/250px-Beursplein_5_%28cropped_and_edited%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Beursplein_5_(cropped_and_edited).jpg) The [Amsterdam Stock Exchange](/wiki/Amsterdam_Stock_Exchange "Amsterdam Stock Exchange"), the oldest stock exchange in the world [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/ZuidasAmsterdamNederland2011.jpg/250px-ZuidasAmsterdamNederland2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:ZuidasAmsterdamNederland2011.jpg) The [Zuidas](/wiki/Zuidas "Zuidas"), the city's main business district

Amsterdam is the financial and business capital of the Netherlands.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-ez-181)^ According to the 2007 [European Cities Monitor](/w/index.php?title=European_Cities_Monitor&action=edit&redlink=1 "European Cities Monitor (page does not exist)") (ECM) -- an annual location survey of Europe's leading companies carried out by global real estate consultant [Cushman \& Wakefield](/wiki/Cushman_%26_Wakefield "Cushman & Wakefield") -- Amsterdam is one of the top European cities in which to locate an [international business](/wiki/International_business "International business"), ranking fifth in the survey.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-eubusiness-182)^ with the survey determining London, Paris, [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt") and [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") as the four European cities surpassing Amsterdam in this regard.{#cite_ref-eubusiness_182-0}

A substantial number of large corporations and banks' headquarters are located in the Amsterdam area, including: [AkzoNobel](/wiki/AkzoNobel "AkzoNobel"), [Heineken International](/wiki/Heineken_International "Heineken International"), [ING Group](/wiki/ING_Group "ING Group"), [ABN AMRO](/wiki/ABN_AMRO "ABN AMRO"), [TomTom](/wiki/TomTom "TomTom"), [Delta Lloyd Group](/wiki/Delta_Lloyd_Group "Delta Lloyd Group"), [Booking.com](/wiki/Booking.com "Booking.com") and [Philips](/wiki/Philips "Philips"). Although many small offices remain along the [historic canals](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), centrally based companies have increasingly relocated outside [Amsterdam's city centre](/wiki/Amsterdam-Centrum "Amsterdam-Centrum"). Consequently, the [Zuidas](/wiki/Zuidas "Zuidas") (English: South Axis) has become the new financial and legal hub of Amsterdam,^[\[182\]](#cite_note-zuidas-183)^ with the country's five largest law firms and several subsidiaries of large consulting firms, such as [Boston Consulting Group](/wiki/Boston_Consulting_Group "Boston Consulting Group") and [Accenture](/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), as well as the [World Trade Centre (Amsterdam)](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(Amsterdam) "World Trade Center (Amsterdam)") located in the [Zuidas](/wiki/Zuidas "Zuidas") district. In addition to the Zuidas, there are three smaller [financial districts](/wiki/Central_business_district "Central business district") in Amsterdam:{#cite_ref-zuidas_183-0}

* around [Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Sloterdijk_railway_station "Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station"). Where one can find the offices of several newspapers, such as *[De Telegraaf](/wiki/De_Telegraaf "De Telegraaf").* as well as those of [Deloitte](/wiki/Deloitte "Deloitte"), the [Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf](/wiki/Gemeentelijk_Vervoerbedrijf "Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf") (municipal public transport company), and the [Dutch tax offices](/wiki/Tax_and_Customs_Administration "Tax and Customs Administration") (*Belastingdienst*);
* around the [Johan Cruyff Arena](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena") in [Amsterdam Zuidoost](/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuidoost "Amsterdam Zuidoost"), with the headquarters of [ING Group](/wiki/ING_Group "ING Group");
* around the [Amstel railway station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Amstel_railway_station "Amsterdam Amstel railway station") in the [Amsterdam-Oost](/wiki/Amsterdam-Oost "Amsterdam-Oost") district to the east of the historical city. Amsterdam's [tallest building](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures_in_the_world "List of tallest buildings and structures in the world"), the [Rembrandt Tower](/wiki/Rembrandt_Tower "Rembrandt Tower"), is located here.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-rembrandtoren-184)^ As are the headquarters of [Philips](/wiki/Philips "Philips"), the Dutch multinational conglomerate.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-philips-185)^ Amsterdam has been a leading city to reduce the use of [raw materials](/wiki/Raw_material "Raw material") and has created a plan to become a [circular city](/wiki/Circular_economy "Circular economy") by 2050.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

The adjoining municipality of [Amstelveen](/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen") is the location of [KPMG International's](/wiki/KPMG "KPMG") global headquarters. Other non-Dutch companies have chosen to settle in communities surrounding Amsterdam since they allow [freehold](/wiki/Freehold_(law) "Freehold (law)") property ownership, whereas Amsterdam retains [ground rent](/wiki/Ground_rent "Ground rent").

The [Amsterdam Stock Exchange](/wiki/Amsterdam_Stock_Exchange "Amsterdam Stock Exchange") (AEX), now part of [Euronext](/wiki/Euronext "Euronext"), is the world's oldest stock exchange and, due to [Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit"), has overtaken [LSE](/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange "London Stock Exchange") as the largest bourse in Europe.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-187)^ It is near [Dam Square](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square") in the city centre.{#cite_ref-187}  

### Port of Amsterdam {#Port_of_Amsterdam}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Port of Amsterdam")\]

The [Port of Amsterdam](/wiki/Port_of_Amsterdam "Port of Amsterdam") is the fourth-largest port in Europe, the 38th largest port in the world, and the second-largest port in the Netherlands by metric tons of cargo. In 2014, the Port of Amsterdam had a cargo throughput of 97,4 million tons of cargo, which was mostly [bulk cargo](/wiki/Bulk_cargo "Bulk cargo"). Amsterdam has the biggest cruise port in the Netherlands with more than 150 cruise ships every year. In 2019, the new lock in [IJmuiden](/wiki/IJmuiden "IJmuiden") opened; since then, the port has been able to grow to 125 million tonnes in capacity.  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Tourism")\]  
Main article: [List of tourist attractions in Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_tourist_attractions_in_Amsterdam "List of tourist attractions in Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Wim_Sonneveld_tour_boat%2C_Rederij_Lovers%2C_Amsterdam-9218.jpg/220px-Wim_Sonneveld_tour_boat%2C_Rederij_Lovers%2C_Amsterdam-9218.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wim_Sonneveld_tour_boat,_Rederij_Lovers,_Amsterdam-9218.jpg) Boats give tours of the city, such as this one in front of the [EYE Film Institute Netherlands](/wiki/EYE_Film_Institute_Netherlands "EYE Film Institute Netherlands"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Brug_97_in_de_Spiegelgracht_over_de_Lijnbaansgracht_foto_1.jpg/220px-Brug_97_in_de_Spiegelgracht_over_de_Lijnbaansgracht_foto_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Brug_97_in_de_Spiegelgracht_over_de_Lijnbaansgracht_foto_1.jpg) Spiegelgracht

Amsterdam is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Europe, receiving more than 5.34 million international visitors annually; this is excluding the 16 million day-trippers visiting the city every year.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-ams2009-188)^ The number of visitors has been growing steadily over the past decade. This can be attributed to an increasing number of European visitors. Two-thirds of the hotels are located in the city's centre.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-Maps_of_the_Netherlands-189)^ Hotels with four or five stars contribute 42% of the total beds available and 41% of the overnight stays in Amsterdam. The room occupation rate was 85% in 2017, up from 78% in 2006.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-Dutch_Hotel_City_Index_2019-190)^^[\[190\]](#cite_note-TourismReport-191)^ The majority of tourists (74%) originate from Europe. The largest group of non-European visitors come from the United States, accounting for 14% of the total.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-TourismReport-191)^ Certain years have a theme in Amsterdam to attract extra tourists. For example, the year 2006 was designated "Rembrandt 400", to celebrate the 400th birthday of [Rembrandt van Rijn](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"). Some hotels offer special arrangements or activities during these years. The average number of guests per year staying at the four campsites around the city ranges from 12,000 to 65,000.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-TourismReport-191)^{#cite_ref-TourismReport_191-2}

In 2023, the city began running a campaign to dissuade British men between the ages of 18 and 35 from coming to the city as tourists. The ad shows young men being handcuffed by police and is part of a new campaign to clean up the city's reputation.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-192)^ On 25 May 2023, in a bid to crackdown on wild tourist behaviour, the city banned weed smoking in public areas in and around the red light district.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-193)^{#cite_ref-193}  

#### De Wallen (red-light district) {#De_Wallen_.28red-light_district.29}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: De Wallen (red-light district)")\]

{#Red_light_district}  
Main article: [De Wallen](/wiki/De_Wallen "De Wallen")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Red-light_district_of_Amsterdam_by_day._2012.JPG/220px-Red-light_district_of_Amsterdam_by_day._2012.JPG)](/wiki/File:Red-light_district_of_Amsterdam_by_day._2012.JPG) [De Wallen](/wiki/De_Wallen "De Wallen"), Amsterdam's [Red-light district](/wiki/Red-light_district "Red-light district"), offers activities such as legal [prostitution](/wiki/Prostitution_in_the_Netherlands "Prostitution in the Netherlands") and a number of [coffee shops](/wiki/Coffeeshop_(Netherlands) "Coffeeshop (Netherlands)") that sell [cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis_(drug) "Cannabis (drug)"). It is one of the main tourist attractions.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-194)^

De Wallen, also known as Walletjes or Rosse Buurt, is a designated area for [legalised prostitution](/wiki/Prostitution_in_the_Netherlands "Prostitution in the Netherlands") and is Amsterdam's largest and best-known [red-light district](/wiki/Red-light_district "Red-light district"). This neighbourhood has become a famous attraction for tourists. It consists of a network of canals, streets, and alleys containing several hundred small, one-room apartments rented by [sex workers](/wiki/Sex_worker "Sex worker") who offer their services from behind a window or glass door, typically illuminated with red lights. In recent years, the city government has been closing and repurposing the famous red-light district windows to clean up the area and reduce the amount of party and sex tourism.  

### Retail {#Retail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Retail")\]

Shops in Amsterdam range from large high-end department stores such as [De Bijenkorf](/wiki/De_Bijenkorf "De Bijenkorf") founded in 1870 to small specialty shops. Amsterdam's high-end shops are found in the streets [P.C. Hooftstraat](/wiki/P.C._Hooftstraat "P.C. Hooftstraat")^[\[194\]](#cite_note-hoof_cite-195)^ and *Cornelis Schuytstraat* , which are located in the vicinity of the [Vondelpark](/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark"). One of Amsterdam's busiest high streets is the narrow, medieval [Kalverstraat](/wiki/Kalverstraat "Kalverstraat") in the heart of the city. Other shopping areas include the *Negen Straatjes* and Haarlemmerdijk and Haarlemmerstraat. *Negen Straatjes* are nine narrow streets within the *Grachtengordel* , the concentric canal system of Amsterdam. The Negen Straatjes differ from other shopping districts with the presence of a large diversity of privately owned shops. The Haarlemmerstraat and Haarlemmerdijk were voted the best shopping street in the Netherlands in 2011. These streets have as the *Negen Straatjes* a large diversity of privately owned shops. However, as the *Negen Straatjes* is dominated by fashion stores, the Haarlemmerstraat and Haarlemmerdijk offer a wide variety of stores, just to name some specialties: candy and other food-related stores, lingerie, sneakers, wedding clothing, interior shops, books, Italian deli's, racing and mountain bikes, skatewear, etc.^\[*[original research?](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original research")*\]^{#cite_ref-hoof_cite_195-0}

The city also features a large number of open-air markets such as the [Albert Cuyp Market](/wiki/Albert_Cuyp_Market "Albert Cuyp Market"), Westerstraat-markt, Ten Katemarkt, and [Dappermarkt](/wiki/Dappermarkt "Dappermarkt"). Some of these markets are held daily, like the Albert Cuypmarkt and the Dappermarkt. Others, like the Westerstraatmarkt, are held every week.^\[*[original research?](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original research")*\]^  

### Fashion {#Fashion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Fashion")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/AmsterdamBikeGirl.png/220px-AmsterdamBikeGirl.png)](/wiki/File:AmsterdamBikeGirl.png) An Amsterdammer waits for a traffic light to change at the Muntplein in the heart of Amsterdam.

Several fashion brands and designers are based in Amsterdam. Fashion designers include [Iris van Herpen](/wiki/Iris_van_Herpen "Iris van Herpen"),^[\[195\]](#cite_note-196)^ [Mart Visser](/wiki/Mart_Visser "Mart Visser"), [Viktor \& Rolf](/wiki/Viktor_%26_Rolf "Viktor & Rolf"), [Marlies Dekkers](/wiki/Marlies_Dekkers "Marlies Dekkers") and [Frans Molenaar](/wiki/Frans_Molenaar "Frans Molenaar"). Fashion models like [Yfke Sturm](/wiki/Yfke_Sturm "Yfke Sturm"), [Doutzen Kroes](/wiki/Doutzen_Kroes "Doutzen Kroes") and Kim Noorda started their careers in Amsterdam. Amsterdam has its garment centre in the World Fashion Center. Fashion photographers [Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin](/wiki/Inez_and_Vinoodh "Inez and Vinoodh") were born in Amsterdam.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-197)^{#cite_ref-197}
