[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Van_Gogh_Museum%2C_Kurokawa_wing.jpg/220px-Van_Gogh_Museum%2C_Kurokawa_wing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Van_Gogh_Museum,_Kurokawa_wing.jpg) The [Van Gogh Museum](/wiki/Van_Gogh_Museum "Van Gogh Museum") houses the world's largest collection of [Van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh")'s paintings and letters. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/De_nieuwe_vleugel_van_het_Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-De_nieuwe_vleugel_van_het_Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:De_nieuwe_vleugel_van_het_Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam.jpg) The [Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam](/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam") is an international museum dedicated to modern and contemporary art and design.

During the later part of the 16th century, Amsterdam's Rederijkerskamer ([Chamber of rhetoric](/wiki/Chamber_of_rhetoric "Chamber of rhetoric")) organised contests between different Chambers in the reading of poetry and drama.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-198)^^[\[198\]](#cite_note-199)^ In 1637, [Schouwburg](/wiki/Schouwburg "Schouwburg"), the first theatre in Amsterdam was built, opening on 3 January 1638.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-200)^ The first ballet performances in the Netherlands were given in Schouwburg in 1642 with the *Ballet of the Five Senses* .^[\[200\]](#cite_note-201)^^[\[201\]](#cite_note-202)^ In the 18th century, French theatre became popular. While Amsterdam was under the influence of German music in the 19th century there were few national opera productions; the Hollandse Opera of Amsterdam was built in 1888 for the specific purpose of promoting Dutch opera.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-203)^ In the 19th century, popular culture was centred on the Nes area in Amsterdam (mainly [vaudeville](/wiki/Vaudeville "Vaudeville") and [music-hall](/wiki/Music_hall "Music hall")).^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ An improved [metronome](/wiki/Metronome "Metronome") was invented in 1812 by [Dietrich Nikolaus Winkel](/wiki/Dietrich_Nikolaus_Winkel "Dietrich Nikolaus Winkel").^[\[203\]](#cite_note-204)^ The [Rijksmuseum](/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum") (1885) and [Stedelijk Museum](/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam") (1895) were built and opened.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-205)^^[\[205\]](#cite_note-206)^ In 1888, the [Concertgebouworkest](/wiki/Royal_Concertgebouw_Orchestra "Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra") orchestra was established.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-207)^ With the 20th century came cinema, radio and television.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Though most studios are located in [Hilversum](/wiki/Hilversum "Hilversum") and [Aalsmeer](/wiki/Aalsmeer "Aalsmeer"), Amsterdam's influence on programming is very strong. Many people who work in the television industry live in Amsterdam. Also, the headquarters of the Dutch [SBS Broadcasting Group](/wiki/SBS_6 "SBS 6") is located in Amsterdam.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-sbs6-208)^{#cite_ref-sbs6_208-0}  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Museums")\]

The most important museums of Amsterdam are located on the [Museumplein](/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") (Museum Square), located at the southwestern side of the Rijksmuseum. It was created in the last quarter of the 19th century on the grounds of the former [World's fair](/wiki/Internationale_Koloniale_en_Uitvoerhandel_Tentoonstelling "Internationale Koloniale en Uitvoerhandel Tentoonstelling"). The northeastern part of the square is bordered by the large Rijksmuseum. In front of the Rijksmuseum on the square itself is a long, rectangular pond. This is transformed into an ice rink in winter.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-ijsbaan-209)^ The northwestern part of the square is bordered by the Van Gogh Museum, House of Bols Cocktail \& Genever Experience and Coster Diamonds. The southwestern border of the Museum Square is the Van Baerlestraat, which is a major thoroughfare in this part of Amsterdam. The Concertgebouw is located across this street from the square. To the southeast of the square are several large houses, one of which contains the American consulate. A [parking garage](/wiki/Multi-storey_car_park "Multi-storey car park") can be found underneath the square, as well as a supermarket. The Museumplein is covered almost entirely with a lawn, except for the northeastern part of the square which is covered with gravel. The current appearance of the square was realised in 1999 when the square was remodelled. The square itself is the most prominent site in Amsterdam for festivals and outdoor concerts, especially in the summer. Plans were made in 2008 to remodel the square again because many inhabitants of Amsterdam are not happy with its current appearance.^[\[209\]](#cite_note-museumpleinfacelift-210)^{#cite_ref-museumpleinfacelift_210-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Rembrandt.JPG/180px-Rembrandt.JPG)](/wiki/File:Rembrandt.JPG) [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt") monument on [Rembrandtplein](/wiki/Rembrandtplein "Rembrandtplein")

The [Rijksmuseum](/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum") possesses the largest and most important collection of classical [Dutch art](/wiki/Dutch_art "Dutch art").^[\[210\]](#cite_note-211)^ It opened in 1885. Its collection consists of nearly one million objects.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-212)^ The artist most associated with Amsterdam is [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"), whose work, and the work of his pupils, is displayed in the Rijksmuseum. Rembrandt's masterpiece *[The Night Watch](/wiki/The_Night_Watch "The Night Watch")* is one of the top pieces of art in the museum. It also houses paintings from artists like [Bartholomeus van der Helst](/wiki/Bartholomeus_van_der_Helst "Bartholomeus van der Helst"), [Johannes Vermeer](/wiki/Johannes_Vermeer "Johannes Vermeer"), [Frans Hals](/wiki/Frans_Hals "Frans Hals"), [Ferdinand Bol](/wiki/Ferdinand_Bol "Ferdinand Bol"), [Albert Cuyp](/wiki/Aelbert_Cuyp "Aelbert Cuyp"), [Jacob van Ruisdael](/wiki/Jacob_van_Ruisdael "Jacob van Ruisdael") and [Paulus Potter](/wiki/Paulus_Potter "Paulus Potter"). Aside from paintings, the collection consists of a large variety of [decorative art](/wiki/Decorative_arts "Decorative arts"). This ranges from [Delftware](/wiki/Delftware "Delftware") to giant doll-houses from the 17th century. The architect of the [gothic revival](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture") building was P.J.H. Cuypers. The museum underwent a 10-year, 375 million euro renovation starting in 2003. The full collection was reopened to the public on 13 April 2013 and the Rijksmuseum has remained the most visited museum in Amsterdam with 2.2 million visitors in 2016 and 2.16 million in 2017.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-213)^{#cite_ref-213}

Van Gogh lived in Amsterdam for a short while and there is a [museum dedicated to his work](/wiki/Van_Gogh_Museum "Van Gogh Museum"). The museum is housed in one of the few modern buildings in this area of Amsterdam. The building was designed by [Gerrit Rietveld](/wiki/Gerrit_Rietveld "Gerrit Rietveld"). This building is where the permanent collection is displayed. A new building was added to the museum in 1999. This building, known as the performance wing, was designed by Japanese architect [Kisho Kurokawa](/wiki/Kisho_Kurokawa "Kisho Kurokawa"). Its purpose is to house temporary exhibitions of the museum.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-vangogh3-214)^^[\[214\]](#cite_note-215)^ Some of Van Gogh's most famous paintings, like *[The Potato Eaters](/wiki/The_Potato_Eaters "The Potato Eaters")* and *[Sunflowers](/wiki/Sunflowers_(series_of_paintings) "Sunflowers (series of paintings)")* , are in the collection.^[\[215\]](#cite_note-216)^ The Van Gogh museum is the second most visited museum in Amsterdam, not far behind the Rijksmuseum in terms of the number of visits, being approximately 2.1 million in 2016,^[\[216\]](#cite_note-217)^ for example.{#cite_ref-217}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Nederlands_Scheepvaartmuseum_2024.jpg/220px-Nederlands_Scheepvaartmuseum_2024.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nederlands_Scheepvaartmuseum_2024.jpg) [Het Scheepvaartmuseum](/wiki/Het_Scheepvaartmuseum "Het Scheepvaartmuseum")

Next to the Van Gogh Museum stands the [Stedelijk Museum](/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam"). This is Amsterdam's most important museum of modern art. The museum is as old as the square it borders and was opened in 1895. The permanent collection consists of works of art from artists like [Piet Mondrian](/wiki/Piet_Mondrian "Piet Mondrian"), [Karel Appel](/wiki/Karel_Appel "Karel Appel"), and [Kazimir Malevich](/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich "Kazimir Malevich"). After renovations lasting several years, the museum opened in September 2012 with a new composite extension that has been called 'The Bathtub' due to its resemblance to one.

Amsterdam contains many other museums throughout the city. They range from small museums such as the [Verzetsmuseum](/wiki/Verzetsmuseum "Verzetsmuseum") (Resistance Museum), the [Anne Frank House](/wiki/Anne_Frank_House "Anne Frank House"), and the [Rembrandt House Museum](/wiki/Rembrandt_House_Museum "Rembrandt House Museum"), to the very large, like the [Tropenmuseum](/wiki/Tropenmuseum "Tropenmuseum") (Museum of the Tropics), [Amsterdam Museum](/wiki/Amsterdam_Museum "Amsterdam Museum") (formerly known as Amsterdam Historical Museum), [H'ART Museum](/wiki/H%27ART_Museum "H'ART Museum") and the [Joods Historisch Museum](/wiki/Joods_Historisch_Museum "Joods Historisch Museum") (Jewish Historical Museum). The modern-styled [Nemo](/wiki/NEMO_(museum) "NEMO (museum)") is dedicated to child-friendly science exhibitions.  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Music")\]  
Further information: [List of songs about Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_songs_about_Amsterdam "List of songs about Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Coldplay_perform_%22Adventure_of_a_Lifetime%22%2C_Amsterdam_Arena%2C_June_2016_%285%29.jpg/220px-Coldplay_perform_%22Adventure_of_a_Lifetime%22%2C_Amsterdam_Arena%2C_June_2016_%285%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coldplay_perform_%22Adventure_of_a_Lifetime%22,_Amsterdam_Arena,_June_2016_(5).jpg) [Coldplay](/wiki/Coldplay "Coldplay") performing at the [Amsterdam Arena](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena"), 2016

Amsterdam's musical culture includes a large collection of songs that treat the city nostalgically and lovingly. The 1949 song "Aan de Amsterdamse grachten" ("On the canals of Amsterdam") was performed and recorded by many artists, including [John Kraaijkamp Sr.](/wiki/John_Kraaijkamp_Sr. "John Kraaijkamp Sr."); the best-known version is probably that by [Wim Sonneveld](/wiki/Wim_Sonneveld "Wim Sonneveld") (1962). In the 1950s [Johnny Jordaan](/wiki/Johnny_Jordaan "Johnny Jordaan") rose to fame with "[Geef mij maar Amsterdam](/wiki/Geef_mij_maar_Amsterdam "Geef mij maar Amsterdam")" ("I prefer Amsterdam"), which praises the city above all others (explicitly Paris); Jordaan sang especially about his own neighbourhood, the [Jordaan](/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") ("Bij ons in de Jordaan"). Colleagues and contemporaries of Johnny include [Tante Leen](/wiki/Tante_Leen "Tante Leen") and [Manke Nelis](/wiki/Manke_Nelis "Manke Nelis"). Another notable Amsterdam song is "[Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam_(Jacques_Brel_song) "Amsterdam (Jacques Brel song)")" by [Jacques Brel](/wiki/Jacques_Brel "Jacques Brel") (1964).^[\[217\]](#cite_note-lijflied_finale-218)^ A 2011 poll by Amsterdam newspaper *[Het Parool](/wiki/Het_Parool "Het Parool")* that Trio Bier's "Oude Wolf" was voted "Amsterdams lijflied".^[\[218\]](#cite_note-219)^ Notable Amsterdam bands from the modern era include the [Osdorp Posse](/wiki/Osdorp_Posse "Osdorp Posse") and [The Ex](/wiki/The_Ex_(band) "The Ex (band)").{#cite_ref-219}

[AFAS Live](/wiki/AFAS_Live "AFAS Live") (formerly known as the Heineken Music Hall) is a concert hall located near the [Johan Cruyff Arena](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena") (known as the Amsterdam Arena until 2018). Its main purpose is to serve as a podium for pop concerts for big audiences. Many famous international artists have performed there. Two other notable venues, [Paradiso](/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)") and the [Melkweg](/wiki/Melkweg "Melkweg") are located near the [Leidseplein](/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein"). Both focus on broad programming, ranging from [indie rock](/wiki/Indie_rock "Indie rock") to [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music"), R\&B, and other popular genres. Other subcultural music venues are [OCCII](/wiki/OCCII "OCCII"), [OT301](/wiki/OT301 "OT301"), De Nieuwe Anita, Winston Kingdom, and Zaal 100. [Jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") has a strong following in Amsterdam, with the [Bimhuis](/wiki/Bimhuis "Bimhuis") being the premier venue. In 2012, [Ziggo Dome](/wiki/Ziggo_Dome "Ziggo Dome") was opened, also near Amsterdam Arena, a state-of-the-art indoor music arena.

[AFAS Live](/wiki/AFAS_Live "AFAS Live") is also host to many [electronic dance music](/wiki/Electronic_dance_music "Electronic dance music") festivals, alongside many other venues. [Armin van Buuren](/wiki/Armin_van_Buuren "Armin van Buuren") and [Tiesto](/wiki/Tiesto "Tiesto"), some of the world's leading [Trance](/wiki/Trance_music "Trance music") DJs hail from the Netherlands and frequently perform in Amsterdam. Each year in October, the city hosts the [Amsterdam Dance Event](/wiki/Amsterdam_Dance_Event "Amsterdam Dance Event") (ADE) which is one of the leading electronic music conferences and one of the biggest club festivals for electronic music in the world, attracting over 350,000 visitors each year.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-220)^ Another popular dance festival is 5daysoff, which takes place in the venues [Paradiso](/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)") and [Melkweg](/wiki/Melkweg "Melkweg"). In the summertime, there are several big outdoor dance parties in or nearby Amsterdam, such as Awakenings, [Dance Valley](/wiki/Dance_Valley "Dance Valley"), [Mystery Land](/wiki/Mysteryland "Mysteryland"), Loveland, A Day at the Park, Welcome to the Future, and Valtifest.{#cite_ref-220}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Concertgebouw%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_22-24_HDR.jpg/220px-Concertgebouw%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_22-24_HDR.jpg)](/wiki/File:Concertgebouw,_%C3%81msterdam,_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos,_2016-05-30,_DD_22-24_HDR.jpg) The [Concertgebouw](/wiki/Concertgebouw,_Amsterdam "Concertgebouw, Amsterdam") or Royal Concert Hall houses performances of the [Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra](/wiki/Royal_Concertgebouw_Orchestra "Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra") and other musical events.

Amsterdam has a world-class symphony orchestra, the [Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra](/wiki/Royal_Concertgebouw_Orchestra "Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra"). Their home is the [Concertgebouw](/wiki/Concertgebouw,_Amsterdam "Concertgebouw, Amsterdam"), which is across the Van Baerlestraat from the Museum Square. It is considered by critics to be a [concert hall](/wiki/List_of_concert_halls "List of concert halls") with some of the best [acoustics](/wiki/Acoustics "Acoustics") in the world. The building contains three halls, Grote Zaal, Kleine Zaal, and Spiegelzaal. Some nine hundred concerts and other events per year take place in the Concertgebouw, for a public of over 700,000, making it one of the most-visited concert halls in the world.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-221)^ The opera house of Amsterdam is located adjacent to the city hall. Therefore, the two buildings combined are often called the [Stopera](/wiki/Stopera "Stopera"), (a word originally coined by protesters against its very construction: *Stop the Opera\[-house\]* ). This huge modern complex, opened in 1986, lies in the former Jewish neighbourhood at *Waterlooplein* next to the river [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel"). The *Stopera* is the home base of [Dutch National Opera](/wiki/Dutch_National_Opera "Dutch National Opera"), [Dutch National Ballet](/wiki/Dutch_National_Ballet "Dutch National Ballet") and the [Holland Symfonia](/wiki/Holland_Symfonia "Holland Symfonia"). [Muziekgebouw aan 't IJ](/wiki/Muziekgebouw_aan_%27t_IJ "Muziekgebouw aan 't IJ") is a concert hall, which is located in the [IJ](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") near the central station. Its concerts perform mostly [modern classical music](/wiki/20th-century_classical_music "20th-century classical music"). Located adjacent to it, is the *[Bimhuis](/wiki/Bimhuis "Bimhuis")* , a concert hall for improvised and [Jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") music.{#cite_ref-221}  

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]

Amsterdam has three main theatre buildings.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stadsschouwburg_amsterdam.jpg/220px-Stadsschouwburg_amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stadsschouwburg_amsterdam.jpg) [Stadsschouwburg](/wiki/Stadsschouwburg "Stadsschouwburg"), Amsterdam's best-known theatre [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Theater_carre.jpg/220px-Theater_carre.jpg)](/wiki/File:Theater_carre.jpg) [Royal Theater Carré](/wiki/Royal_Theater_Carr%C3%A9 "Royal Theater Carré"), It was originally meant as a permanent circus building.

The [Stadsschouwburg](/wiki/Stadsschouwburg "Stadsschouwburg") at the [Leidseplein](/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein") is the home base of [Toneelgroep Amsterdam](/wiki/Toneelgroep_Amsterdam "Toneelgroep Amsterdam"). The current building dates from 1894. Most plays are performed in the Grote Zaal (Great Hall). The normal program of events encompasses all sorts of theatrical forms. In 2009, the new hall of the Stadsschouwburg Amsterdam, Toneelgroep Amsterdam, and Melkweg opened, and the renovation of the front end of the theatre was ready.

The [Dutch National Opera and Ballet](/wiki/Stopera "Stopera") (formerly known as *Het Muziektheater* ), dating from 1986, is the principal opera house and home to [Dutch National Opera](/wiki/Dutch_National_Opera "Dutch National Opera") and [Dutch National Ballet](/wiki/Dutch_National_Ballet "Dutch National Ballet"). [Royal Theatre Carré](/wiki/Carr%C3%A9_Theatre "Carré Theatre") was built as a permanent circus theatre in 1887 and is currently mainly used for musicals, [cabaret](/wiki/Cabaret "Cabaret") performances, and pop concerts.

The recently re-opened DeLaMar Theater houses more commercial plays and musicals. A new theatre has also moved into the Amsterdam scene in 2014, joining other established venues: Theater Amsterdam is located in the west part of Amsterdam, on the Danzigerkade. It is housed in a modern building with a panoramic view over the harbour. The theatre is the first-ever purpose-built venue to showcase a single play entitled ANNE, the play based on Anne Frank's life.

On the east side of town, there is a small theatre in a converted bathhouse, the [Badhuistheater](/wiki/Badhuistheater "Badhuistheater"). The theatre often has English programming.

The Netherlands has a tradition of cabaret or *kleinkunst* , which combines music, storytelling, commentary, theatre, and comedy. Cabaret dates back to the 1930s and artists like [Wim Kan](/wiki/Wim_Kan "Wim Kan"), [Wim Sonneveld](/wiki/Wim_Sonneveld "Wim Sonneveld"), and [Toon Hermans](/wiki/Toon_Hermans "Toon Hermans") were pioneers of this form of art in the Netherlands. In Amsterdam are the Kleinkunstacademie (English: Cabaret Academy) and Nederlied Kleinkunstkoor (English: Cabaret Choir). Contemporary popular artists are [Youp van 't Hek](/wiki/Youp_van_%27t_Hek "Youp van 't Hek"), [Freek de Jonge](/wiki/Freek_de_Jonge "Freek de Jonge"), [Herman Finkers](/wiki/Herman_Finkers "Herman Finkers"), [Hans Teeuwen](/wiki/Hans_Teeuwen "Hans Teeuwen"), [Theo Maassen](/wiki/Theo_Maassen "Theo Maassen"), [Herman van Veen](/wiki/Herman_van_Veen "Herman van Veen"), [Najib Amhali](/wiki/Najib_Amhali "Najib Amhali"), [Raoul Heertje](/wiki/Raoul_Heertje "Raoul Heertje"), [Jörgen Raymann](/wiki/J%C3%B6rgen_Raymann "Jörgen Raymann"), [Brigitte Kaandorp](/wiki/Brigitte_Kaandorp "Brigitte Kaandorp") and [Comedytrain](/wiki/Comedytrain "Comedytrain"). The English-spoken comedy scene was established with the founding of [Boom Chicago](/wiki/Boom_Chicago "Boom Chicago") in 1993. They have their own theatre at Leidseplein.  

### Nightlife {#Nightlife}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Nightlife")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/DeWolff_Paradiso.jpg/200px-DeWolff_Paradiso.jpg)](/wiki/File:DeWolff_Paradiso.jpg)  
DeWolff performing at [Paradiso](/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Amsterdam_Magere_Brug.jpg/200px-Amsterdam_Magere_Brug.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Magere_Brug.jpg)  
The [Magere Brug](/wiki/Magere_Brug "Magere Brug") or "Skinny Bridge" over the [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel") at night

Amsterdam is famous for its vibrant and diverse nightlife. Amsterdam has many *[cafés](/wiki/Bar_(establishment) "Bar (establishment)")* (bars). They range from large and modern to small and cosy. The typical *Bruine Kroeg* (brown *café* ) breathes a more old-fashioned atmosphere with dimmed lights, candles, and somewhat older clientele. These brown cafés mostly offer a wide range of local and international artisanal beers. Most *cafés* have terraces in summertime. A common sight on the Leidseplein during summer is a square full of terraces packed with people drinking beer or wine. Many restaurants can be found in Amsterdam as well. Since Amsterdam is a multicultural city, a lot of different ethnic restaurants can be found. Restaurants range from being rather luxurious and expensive to being ordinary and affordable. Amsterdam also possesses many [discothèques](/wiki/Discoth%C3%A8que "Discothèque"). The two main nightlife areas for tourists are the [Leidseplein](/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein") and the [Rembrandtplein](/wiki/Rembrandtplein "Rembrandtplein"). The [Paradiso](/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)"), [Melkweg](/wiki/Melkweg "Melkweg") and Sugar Factory are cultural centres, which turn into discothèques on some nights.  

### Festivals {#Festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Festivals")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Queen%27s_Day_in_Amsterdam_2013_%288697415382%29.jpg/200px-Queen%27s_Day_in_Amsterdam_2013_%288697415382%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Queen%27s_Day_in_Amsterdam_2013_(8697415382).jpg)  
[Queen's Day](/wiki/Koningsdag "Koningsdag") in Amsterdam in 2013  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Amsterdam%27s_Canals.jpg/200px-Amsterdam%27s_Canals.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam%27s_Canals.jpg)  
People dressed in orange on the [canals of Amsterdam](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam") in 2010 during [Koningsdag](/wiki/Koningsdag "Koningsdag") or King's Day

In 2008, there were 140 festivals and events in Amsterdam.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-festivals-222)^ During the same year, Amsterdam was designated as the [World Book Capital](/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") for one year by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO").^[\[222\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}

Famous festivals and events in Amsterdam include: *[Koningsdag](/wiki/Koningsdag "Koningsdag")* (which was named *Koninginnedag* until the crowning of King Willem-Alexander in 2013) (King's Day -- Queen's Day); the [Holland Festival](/wiki/Holland_Festival "Holland Festival") for the performing arts; the yearly [Prinsengrachtconcert](/wiki/Prinsengrachtconcert "Prinsengrachtconcert") (classical concerto on the Prinsen canal) in August; the '[Stille Omgang](/wiki/Stille_Omgang "Stille Omgang")' (a silent Roman Catholic evening procession held every March); [Amsterdam Gay Pride](/wiki/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride "Amsterdam Gay Pride"); The [Cannabis Cup](/wiki/Cannabis_Cup "Cannabis Cup"); and the [Uitmarkt](/wiki/Uitmarkt "Uitmarkt"). On Koningsdag---which is held each year on 27 April---hundreds of thousands of people travel to Amsterdam to celebrate with the city's residents. The entire city becomes overcrowded with people buying products from the *free market*, or visiting one of the many music concerts.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride_2013_boat_no37_Hot_Spot_Cafe_pic7.JPG/220px-Amsterdam_Gay_Pride_2013_boat_no37_Hot_Spot_Cafe_pic7.JPG)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Gay_Pride_2013_boat_no37_Hot_Spot_Cafe_pic7.JPG) One of the decorated boats participating in the 2013 Canal Parade of the [Amsterdam Gay Pride](/wiki/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride "Amsterdam Gay Pride")

The yearly Holland Festival attracts international artists and visitors from all over Europe. [Amsterdam Gay Pride](/wiki/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride "Amsterdam Gay Pride") is a yearly local LGBT parade of boats in Amsterdam's canals, held on the first Saturday in August.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-gaypride-224)^ The annual Uitmarkt is a three-day cultural event at the start of the cultural season in late August. It offers previews of many different artists, such as musicians and poets, who perform on [podia](/wiki/Podium "Podium").^[\[224\]](#cite_note-uitmarkt-225)^{#cite_ref-uitmarkt_225-0}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
See also: [Football in Amsterdam](/wiki/Football_in_Amsterdam "Football in Amsterdam")

Amsterdam is home of the *[Eredivisie](/wiki/Eredivisie "Eredivisie")* football club [AFC Ajax](/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC Ajax"). The stadium [Johan Cruyff Arena](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena") is the home of Ajax. It is located in the [south-east](/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuidoost "Amsterdam Zuidoost") of the city next to the new [Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Bijlmer_ArenA_railway_station "Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station"). Before moving to their current location in 1996, Ajax played their regular matches in the now demolished [De Meer Stadion](/wiki/De_Meer_Stadion "De Meer Stadion") in the eastern part of the city^[\[225\]](#cite_note-226)^ or in the [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Amsterdam) "Olympic Stadium (Amsterdam)"). In 1928, Amsterdam hosted the [Summer Olympics](/wiki/1928_Summer_Olympics "1928 Summer Olympics"). The [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Amsterdam) "Olympic Stadium (Amsterdam)") built for the occasion has been completely restored and is now used for cultural and sporting events, such as the [Amsterdam Marathon](/wiki/Amsterdam_Marathon "Amsterdam Marathon").^[\[226\]](#cite_note-227)^ In 1920, Amsterdam assisted in hosting some of the [sailing](/wiki/Sailing_at_the_1920_Summer_Olympics "Sailing at the 1920 Summer Olympics") events for the [Summer Olympics](/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics "1920 Summer Olympics") held in neighbouring [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp"), Belgium by hosting events at [Buiten IJ](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)"). They had also made a bid to host the [1952](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics") and [1992 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics "1992 Summer Olympics") but lost to [Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki") and [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona").{#cite_ref-227}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Feyenoord_tegen_Ajax_1-0._Nummer_26_Israel_in_duel_met_Cruyff.jpg/220px-Feyenoord_tegen_Ajax_1-0._Nummer_26_Israel_in_duel_met_Cruyff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Feyenoord_tegen_Ajax_1-0._Nummer_26_Israel_in_duel_met_Cruyff.jpg) [AFC Ajax](/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC Ajax") player [Johan Cruyff](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff "Johan Cruyff"), 1967

The city holds the [Dam to Dam Run](/wiki/Dam_tot_Damloop "Dam tot Damloop"), a 16 km (10 mi) race from Amsterdam to [Zaandam](/wiki/Zaandam "Zaandam"), as well as the [Amsterdam Marathon](/wiki/Amsterdam_Marathon "Amsterdam Marathon"). The ice hockey team [Amstel Tijgers](/wiki/Amstel_Tijgers "Amstel Tijgers") plays in the [Jaap Eden](/wiki/Jaap_Eden "Jaap Eden") ice rink. The team competes in the Dutch Ice Hockey Premier League. [Speed skating](/wiki/Long_track_speed_skating "Long track speed skating") championships have been held on the 400-meter lane of this ice rink.

Amsterdam holds two [American football](/wiki/American_football "American football") franchises: the [Amsterdam Crusaders](/wiki/Amsterdam_Crusaders "Amsterdam Crusaders") and the Amsterdam Panthers. The [Amsterdam Pirates](/wiki/Amsterdam_Pirates "Amsterdam Pirates") baseball team competes in the [Dutch Major League](/wiki/Honkbal_Hoofdklasse "Honkbal Hoofdklasse"). There are three [field hockey](/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey") teams: Amsterdam, Pinoké, and Hurley, who play their matches around the [Wagener Stadium](/wiki/Wagener_Stadium "Wagener Stadium") in the nearby city of [Amstelveen](/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen"). The basketball team [MyGuide Amsterdam](/wiki/MyGuide_Amsterdam "MyGuide Amsterdam") competes in the Dutch premier division and play their games in the Sporthallen Zuid.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-228)^{#cite_ref-228}

There is one rugby club in Amsterdam, which also hosts sports training classes such as RTC (Rugby Talenten Centrum or Rugby Talent Centre) and the National Rugby Stadium.

Since 1999, the city of Amsterdam honours the best sportsmen and women at the [Amsterdam Sports Awards](/wiki/Amsterdam_Sportsman_of_the_year "Amsterdam Sportsman of the year"). Boxer [Raymond Joval](/wiki/Raymond_Joval "Raymond Joval") and field hockey midfielder [Carole Thate](/wiki/Carole_Thate "Carole Thate") were the first to receive the awards, in 1999.

Amsterdam hosted the [World Gymnaestrada](/wiki/World_Gymnaestrada "World Gymnaestrada") in 1991 and will do so again in 2023.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-229)^{#cite_ref-229}  

Politics {#Politics}
--------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Politics")\]  
Main article: [Government of Amsterdam](/wiki/Government_of_Amsterdam "Government of Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Femke_Halsema_2.jpg/200px-Femke_Halsema_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Femke_Halsema_2.jpg) [Femke Halsema](/wiki/Femke_Halsema "Femke Halsema") has been the [Mayor of Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Amsterdam "List of mayors of Amsterdam") since 2018.

The city of Amsterdam is a [municipality](/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") under the Dutch Municipalities Act. It is governed by a directly elected [municipal council](/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)"), a [municipal executive](/wiki/Municipal_executive "Municipal executive"), and a [mayor](/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester"). Since 1981, the [municipality](/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of Amsterdam has gradually been divided into semi-autonomous [boroughs](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam"), called *stadsdelen* or 'districts'. Over time, a total of 15 boroughs were created. In May 2010, under a major reform, the number of [Amsterdam boroughs](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") was reduced to eight: [Amsterdam-Centrum](/wiki/Amsterdam-Centrum "Amsterdam-Centrum") covering the city centre including the [canal belt](/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), [Amsterdam-Noord](/wiki/Amsterdam-Noord "Amsterdam-Noord") consisting of the neighbourhoods north of the [IJ lake](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)"), [Amsterdam-Oost](/wiki/Amsterdam-Oost "Amsterdam-Oost") in the east, [Amsterdam-Zuid](/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuid "Amsterdam-Zuid") in the south, [Amsterdam-West](/wiki/Amsterdam-West "Amsterdam-West") in the west, [Amsterdam Nieuw-West](/wiki/Amsterdam_Nieuw-West "Amsterdam Nieuw-West") in the far west, [Amsterdam Zuidoost](/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuidoost "Amsterdam Zuidoost") in the southeast, and [Westpoort](/wiki/Westpoort_(Amsterdam) "Westpoort (Amsterdam)") covering the [Port of Amsterdam](/wiki/Port_of_Amsterdam "Port of Amsterdam") area.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-230)^{#cite_ref-230}  

### City government {#City_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: City government")\]  
Main articles: [Boroughs of Amsterdam](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") and [Municipal council (Netherlands)](/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)")

As with all Dutch municipalities, Amsterdam is governed by a directly elected [municipal council](/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)"), a [municipal executive](/wiki/Municipal_executive "Municipal executive") and a government appointed^[\[230\]](#cite_note-231)^ [mayor](/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester") (*burgemeester* ). The mayor is a member of the municipal executive board but also has individual responsibilities in maintaining public order. On 27 June 2018, [Femke Halsema](/wiki/Femke_Halsema "Femke Halsema") (former member of [House of Representatives](/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Netherlands) "House of Representatives (Netherlands)") for [GroenLinks](/wiki/GroenLinks "GroenLinks") from 1998 to 2011) was appointed as the first woman to be [Mayor of Amsterdam](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Amsterdam "List of mayors of Amsterdam") by the [King's Commissioner](/wiki/King%27s_Commissioner "King's Commissioner") of [North Holland](/wiki/North_Holland "North Holland") for a six-year term after being nominated by the Amsterdam [municipal council](/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)") and began serving a six-year term on 12 July 2018. She replaces [Eberhard van der Laan](/wiki/Eberhard_van_der_Laan "Eberhard van der Laan") ([Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(Netherlands) "Labour Party (Netherlands)")) who was the Mayor of Amsterdam from 2010 until his death in October 2017. After the [2014 municipal council elections](/wiki/Dutch_municipal_elections,_2014 "Dutch municipal elections, 2014"), a governing majority of [D66](/wiki/Democrats_66 "Democrats 66"), [VVD](/wiki/People%27s_Party_for_Freedom_and_Democracy "People's Party for Freedom and Democracy") and [SP](/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Netherlands) "Socialist Party (Netherlands)") was formed -- the first coalition without the [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(Netherlands) "Labour Party (Netherlands)") since [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").^[\[231\]](#cite_note-232)^ Next to the [Mayor](/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester"), the [municipal executive](/wiki/Municipal_executive "Municipal executive") consists of eight *wethouders* ('alderpersons') appointed by the [municipal council](/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)"): four D66 alderpersons, two VVD alderpersons and two [SP](/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Netherlands) "Socialist Party (Netherlands)") alderpersons.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-233)^{#cite_ref-233}

On 18 September 2017, it was announced by [Eberhard van der Laan](/wiki/Eberhard_van_der_Laan "Eberhard van der Laan") in an open letter to Amsterdam citizens that [Kajsa Ollongren](/wiki/Kajsa_Ollongren "Kajsa Ollongren") would take up his office as acting Mayor of Amsterdam with immediate effect due to ill health.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-234)^ Ollongren was succeeded as acting Mayor by Eric van der Burg on 26 October 2017 and by [Jozias van Aartsen](/wiki/Jozias_van_Aartsen "Jozias van Aartsen") on 4 December 2017.{#cite_ref-234}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Amsterdamse_stadsdelen_2010.png/250px-Amsterdamse_stadsdelen_2010.png)](/wiki/File:Amsterdamse_stadsdelen_2010.png) [Boroughs of Amsterdam](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") until 24 March 2022

Unlike most other Dutch municipalities, Amsterdam is subdivided into seven [boroughs](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam"), called *stadsdelen* or 'districts', and the urban area of [Weesp](/wiki/Weesp "Weesp").^[\[1\]](#cite_note-stadsdelen-1)^ This system was gradually implemented in the 1980s to improve local governance. The boroughs are responsible for many activities that had previously been run by the central city. In 2010, the number of [Amsterdam boroughs](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") reached fifteen. Fourteen of those had their own district council (*deelraad* ), elected by a popular vote. The fifteenth, [Westpoort](/wiki/Westpoort "Westpoort"), covers the harbour of Amsterdam and has very few residents. Therefore, it was governed by the central municipal council.{#cite_ref-stadsdelen_1-1}

Under the borough system, municipal decisions are made at the borough level, except for those affairs on the whole city such as major infrastructure projects, which are the jurisdiction of the central municipal authorities. In 2010, the [borough](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") system was restructured, in which many smaller boroughs merged into larger boroughs. In 2014, under a reform of the Dutch Municipalities Act, the [Amsterdam boroughs](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") lost much of their autonomous status, as their district councils were abolished.

The municipal council of Amsterdam voted to maintain the borough system by replacing the district councils with smaller, but still directly elected district committees (*bestuurscommissies*). Under a municipal ordinance, the new district committees were granted responsibilities through the delegation of regulatory and executive powers by the central municipal council.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Amsterdam_Amstel.jpg/800px-Amsterdam_Amstel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Amstel.jpg) View of the [Stopera](/wiki/Stopera "Stopera") (left), behind the [Blauwbrug](/wiki/Blauwbrug "Blauwbrug") (blue bridge), where the Amsterdam city hall and opera house are located, and the [H'ART Museum](/wiki/H%27ART_Museum "H'ART Museum") (right) on the [Amstel](/wiki/Amstel "Amstel")  

### Metropolitan area {#Metropolitan_area}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Metropolitan area")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Police_Headquarters%2C_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-Police_Headquarters%2C_Amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Police_Headquarters,_Amsterdam.jpg) Police headquarters of Amsterdam

"Amsterdam" is usually understood to refer to the [municipality](/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of Amsterdam. Colloquially, some areas within the municipality, such as the town of [Durgerdam](/wiki/Durgerdam "Durgerdam"), may not be considered part of Amsterdam.

[Statistics Netherlands](/wiki/Statistics_Netherlands "Statistics Netherlands") uses three other definitions of Amsterdam: metropolitan agglomeration Amsterdam (*Grootstedelijke Agglomeratie Amsterdam* , not to be confused with *Grootstedelijk Gebied Amsterdam* , a synonym of *Groot Amsterdam* ), Greater Amsterdam (*Groot Amsterdam* , a [COROP](/wiki/COROP "COROP") region) and the urban region Amsterdam (*Stadsgewest Amsterdam* ).^[\[122\]](#cite_note-auto-123)^ The Amsterdam Department for Research and Statistics uses a fourth conurbation, namely the *Stadsregio Amsterdam* ('City Region of Amsterdam'). The city region is similar to Greater Amsterdam but includes the municipalities of [Zaanstad](/wiki/Zaanstad "Zaanstad") and [Wormerland](/wiki/Wormerland "Wormerland").{#cite_ref-auto_123-2}

The smallest of these areas is the [municipality](/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of Amsterdam with a population of about 870,000 in 2021.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-cbs2021-235)^ The larger conurbation had a population of over one million. It includes the municipalities of Zaanstad, Wormerland, Oostzaan, Diemen, and Amstelveen only, as well as the municipality of Amsterdam. Greater Amsterdam includes 15 municipalities and had a population of 1,400,000 in 2021.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-cbs2021-235)^ Though much larger in area, the population of this area is only slightly larger, because the definition excludes the relatively populous municipality of [Zaanstad](/wiki/Zaanstad "Zaanstad"). The largest area by population, the [Amsterdam Metropolitan Area](/wiki/Amsterdam_Metropolitan_Area "Amsterdam Metropolitan Area") (Dutch: Metropoolregio Amsterdam), has a population of 2,33 million.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-dosamsterdam-236)^ It includes for instance Zaanstad, Wormerland, Muiden, Abcoude, Haarlem, Almere and Lelystad but excludes [Graft-De Rijp](/wiki/Graft-De_Rijp "Graft-De Rijp"). Amsterdam is part of the conglomerate metropolitan area [Randstad](/wiki/Randstad "Randstad"), with a total population of 6,659,300 inhabitants.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-randstad-237)^{#cite_ref-randstad_237-0}

Of these various metropolitan area configurations, only the *Stadsregio Amsterdam* (City Region of Amsterdam) has a formal governmental status. Its responsibilities include regional spatial planning and metropolitan public transport concessions.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-238)^{#cite_ref-238}  

### National capital {#National_capital}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: National capital")\]  
Main article: [Capital of the Netherlands](/wiki/Capital_of_the_Netherlands "Capital of the Netherlands")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/King_Willem-Alexander%2C_Princess_Beatrix_en_Queen_Maxima.jpg/220px-King_Willem-Alexander%2C_Princess_Beatrix_en_Queen_Maxima.jpg)](/wiki/File:King_Willem-Alexander,_Princess_Beatrix_en_Queen_Maxima.jpg) [King Willem-Alexander](/wiki/Willem-Alexander_of_the_Netherlands "Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands"), [Princess Beatrix](/wiki/Beatrix_of_the_Netherlands "Beatrix of the Netherlands"), and [Queen Máxima](/wiki/Queen_M%C3%A1xima_of_the_Netherlands "Queen Máxima of the Netherlands") greeting Amsterdammers from the [Royal Palace of Amsterdam](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam") during Willem-Alexanders inauguration in 2013

Under the [Dutch Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Netherlands "Constitution of the Netherlands"), Amsterdam is the [capital of the Netherlands](/wiki/Capital_of_the_Netherlands "Capital of the Netherlands"). Since the 1983 constitutional revision, the constitution mentions "Amsterdam" and "capital" in chapter 2, article 32: The king's confirmation by oath and his coronation take place in "the capital Amsterdam" ("*de hoofdstad Amsterdam* ").^[\[238\]](#cite_note-capital-constitution-239)^ Previous versions of the constitution only mentioned "the city of Amsterdam" ("*de stad Amsterdam* ").^[\[239\]](#cite_note-240)^ For a royal investiture, therefore, the [States General of the Netherlands](/wiki/States_General_of_the_Netherlands "States General of the Netherlands") (the Dutch Parliament) meets for a ceremonial joint session in Amsterdam. The ceremony traditionally takes place at the [Nieuwe Kerk](/wiki/Nieuwe_Kerk_(Amsterdam) "Nieuwe Kerk (Amsterdam)") on [Dam Square](/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"), immediately after the former monarch has signed the act of abdication at the nearby [Royal Palace of Amsterdam](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam"). Normally, however, the Parliament sits in [The Hague](/wiki/The_Hague "The Hague"), the city which has historically been the seat of the [Dutch government](/wiki/Politics_of_the_Netherlands "Politics of the Netherlands"), the [Dutch monarchy](/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_Netherlands "Monarchy of the Netherlands"), and the [Dutch supreme court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Netherlands "Supreme Court of the Netherlands"). Foreign embassies are also located in The Hague.{#cite_ref-240}  

### Symbols {#Symbols}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Symbols")\]  
Main articles: [Coat of arms of Amsterdam](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Amsterdam "Coat of arms of Amsterdam") and [Flag of Amsterdam](/wiki/Flag_of_Amsterdam "Flag of Amsterdam")

The coat of arms of Amsterdam is composed of several historical elements. First and centre are three [St Andrew's crosses](/wiki/Saltire "Saltire"), aligned in a vertical band on the city's shield (although Amsterdam's [patron saint](/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint") was [Saint Nicholas](/wiki/Saint_Nicholas "Saint Nicholas")). These St Andrew's crosses can also be found on the city shields of neighbours [Amstelveen](/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen") and [Ouder-Amstel](/wiki/Ouder-Amstel "Ouder-Amstel"). This part of the coat of arms is the basis of the [flag of Amsterdam](/wiki/Flag_of_Amsterdam "Flag of Amsterdam"), flown by the city government, but also as [civil ensign](/wiki/Civil_ensign "Civil ensign") for ships registered in Amsterdam. Second is the [Imperial Crown of Austria](/wiki/Imperial_Crown_of_Austria "Imperial Crown of Austria"). In 1489, out of gratitude for services and loans, [Maximilian I](/wiki/Maximilian_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor") awarded Amsterdam the right to adorn its coat of arms with the [king's](/wiki/King_of_the_Romans "King of the Romans") crown. Then, in 1508, this was replaced with Maximilian's [imperial crown](/wiki/Imperial_crown "Imperial crown") when he was crowned [Holy Roman Emperor](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor "Holy Roman Emperor"). In the early years of the 17th century, Maximilian's crown in Amsterdam's coat of arms was again replaced, this time with the crown of [Emperor Rudolph II](/wiki/Rudolf_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor"), a crown that became the Imperial [Crown of Austria](/wiki/Austrian_Crown_Jewels "Austrian Crown Jewels"). The lions date from the late 16th century, when the city and province became part of the [Republic of the Seven United Netherlands](/wiki/Dutch_Republic "Dutch Republic"). Last came the city's official motto: *Heldhaftig, Vastberaden, Barmhartig* ("Heroic, Determined, Merciful"), bestowed on the city in 1947 by [Queen Wilhelmina](/wiki/Wilhelmina_of_the_Netherlands "Wilhelmina of the Netherlands"), in recognition of the city's bravery during the Second World War.  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Amsterdam](/wiki/Transport_in_Amsterdam "Transport in Amsterdam")  

### Metro, tram and bus {#Metro.2C_tram_and_bus}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Metro, tram and bus")\]  
Main articles: [Amsterdam Metro](/wiki/Amsterdam_Metro "Amsterdam Metro") and [Trams in Amsterdam](/wiki/Trams_in_Amsterdam "Trams in Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Amsterdam_-_Keizersgracht_-_1316.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_-_Keizersgracht_-_1316.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_-_Keizersgracht_-_1316.jpg) A tram crossing the Keizersgracht [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/NoordZuidLijn_Metrostation_Europaplein_hnapel_004.jpg/220px-NoordZuidLijn_Metrostation_Europaplein_hnapel_004.jpg)](/wiki/File:NoordZuidLijn_Metrostation_Europaplein_hnapel_004.jpg) The [Amsterdam Metro](/wiki/Amsterdam_Metro "Amsterdam Metro") is a mixed subway and above ground [rapid transit system](/wiki/Rapid_Transit "Rapid Transit") consisting of five lines.

Currently, there are sixteen [tram routes](/wiki/Trams_in_Amsterdam "Trams in Amsterdam") and five [metro routes](/wiki/Amsterdam_Metro "Amsterdam Metro"). All are operated by the municipal public transport operator [Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf](/wiki/Gemeentelijk_Vervoerbedrijf "Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf") (GVB), which also runs the city bus network.

Four fare-free GVB ferries carry pedestrians and cyclists across the [IJ lake](/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") to the [borough](/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") of [Amsterdam-Noord](/wiki/Amsterdam-Noord "Amsterdam-Noord"), and two fare-charging ferries run east and west along the harbour. There are also privately operated water taxis, a water bus, a boat-sharing operation, electric rental boats, and canal cruises, that transport people along Amsterdam's waterways.

Regional buses, and some suburban buses, are operated by [Connexxion](/wiki/Connexxion "Connexxion") and [EBS](/wiki/Egged_(company) "Egged (company)"). International coach services are provided by [Eurolines](/wiki/Eurolines "Eurolines") from [Amsterdam Amstel railway station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Amstel_railway_station "Amsterdam Amstel railway station"), [IDBUS](/wiki/IDBUS "IDBUS") from [Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Sloterdijk_railway_station "Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station"), and [Megabus](/wiki/Megabus_(Europe) "Megabus (Europe)") from the Zuiderzeeweg in the east of the city.

To facilitate easier transport to the centre of Amsterdam, the city has various P+R Locations where people can park their car at an affordable price and transfer to one of the numerous public transport lines.^[\[240\]](#cite_note-241)^{#cite_ref-241}  

### Car {#Car}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Car")\]

Amsterdam was intended in 1932 to be the hub, a kind of [Kilometre Zero](/wiki/Kilometre_Zero "Kilometre Zero"), of the [highway system of the Netherlands](/wiki/List_of_motorways_in_the_Netherlands "List of motorways in the Netherlands"),^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Autosnelweg_1930-242)^ with freeways numbered One to Eight planned to originate from the city.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Autosnelweg_1930-242)^ The outbreak of the Second World War and shifting priorities led to the current situation, where only roads [A1](/wiki/A1_motorway_(Netherlands) "A1 motorway (Netherlands)"), [A2](/wiki/A2_motorway_(Netherlands) "A2 motorway (Netherlands)"), and [A4](/wiki/A4_motorway_(Netherlands) "A4 motorway (Netherlands)") originate from Amsterdam according to the original plan. The [A3](/w/index.php?title=A3_motorway_(Netherlands)&action=edit&redlink=1 "A3 motorway (Netherlands) (page does not exist)") to [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam") was cancelled in 1970 to conserve the [Groene Hart](/wiki/Groene_Hart "Groene Hart"). Road [A8](/wiki/A8_motorway_(Netherlands) "A8 motorway (Netherlands)"), leading north to [Zaandam](/wiki/Zaandam "Zaandam") and the [A10](/wiki/A10_motorway_(Netherlands) "A10 motorway (Netherlands)") [Ringroad](/wiki/Beltway "Beltway") were opened between 1968 and 1974.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-Autosnelweg_1970-243)^ Besides the A1, A2, A4 and A8, several freeways, such as the [A7](/wiki/A7_motorway_(Netherlands) "A7 motorway (Netherlands)") and [A6](/wiki/A6_motorway_(Netherlands) "A6 motorway (Netherlands)"), carry traffic mainly bound for Amsterdam.{#cite_ref-Autosnelweg_1970_243-0}

The [A10 ringroad](/wiki/A10_motorway_(Netherlands) "A10 motorway (Netherlands)") surrounding the city connects Amsterdam with the Dutch [national network of freeways](/wiki/List_of_motorways_in_the_Netherlands "List of motorways in the Netherlands"). [Interchanges](/wiki/Interchange_(road) "Interchange (road)") on the A10 allow cars to enter the city by transferring to one of the 18 *[city roads](/wiki/List_of_city_routes_in_the_Netherlands "List of city routes in the Netherlands")* , numbered S101 through to [S118](/wiki/S118_(Amsterdam) "S118 (Amsterdam)"). These city roads are regional roads without [grade separation](/wiki/Grade_separation "Grade separation"), and sometimes without a [central reservation](/wiki/Central_reservation "Central reservation"). Most are accessible by cyclists. The S100 *Centrumring* is a smaller ring road circumnavigating the city's centre.

In the city centre, driving a car is discouraged. Parking fees are expensive, and many streets are closed to cars or are [one-way](/wiki/One-way_traffic "One-way traffic").^[\[243\]](#cite_note-Fiets-244)^ The local government sponsors [carsharing](/wiki/Carsharing "Carsharing") and [carpooling](/wiki/Carpool "Carpool") initiatives such as *Autodelen* and *Meerijden.nu* .^[\[244\]](#cite_note-cars-245)^ The local government has also started removing parking spaces in the city in 2019, with the goal of removing 10,000 spaces (roughly 1,500 per year) by 2025.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-246)^{#cite_ref-246}  

### National rail {#National_rail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: National rail")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Amsterdam_Central_Station1.jpg/250px-Amsterdam_Central_Station1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Central_Station1.jpg) [Amsterdam Centraal station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_station "Amsterdam Centraal station"), the city's main train station

Amsterdam is served by ten [stations](/wiki/Railway_stations_in_the_Netherlands#A "Railway stations in the Netherlands") of the [Nederlandse Spoorwegen](/wiki/Nederlandse_Spoorwegen "Nederlandse Spoorwegen") (Dutch Railways).^[\[246\]](#cite_note-Stationsweb-247)^ Five are intercity stops: [Sloterdijk](/wiki/Sloterdijk_(Amsterdam) "Sloterdijk (Amsterdam)"), [Zuid](/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuid_railway_station "Amsterdam Zuid railway station"), [Amstel](/wiki/Amsterdam_Amstel_railway_station "Amsterdam Amstel railway station"), [Bijlmer ArenA](/wiki/Amsterdam_Bijlmer_ArenA_railway_station "Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station") and [Amsterdam Centraal](/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_railway_station "Amsterdam Centraal railway station"). The stations for local services are: [Lelylaan](/wiki/Amsterdam_Lelylaan_railway_station "Amsterdam Lelylaan railway station"), [RAI](/wiki/Amsterdam_RAI_railway_station "Amsterdam RAI railway station"), [Holendrecht](/wiki/Amsterdam_Holendrecht_railway_station "Amsterdam Holendrecht railway station"), [Muiderpoort](/wiki/Amsterdam_Muiderpoort_railway_station "Amsterdam Muiderpoort railway station") and [Science Park](/wiki/Amsterdam_Science_Park_railway_station "Amsterdam Science Park railway station"). [Amsterdam Centraal](/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_railway_station "Amsterdam Centraal railway station") is also an international railway station. From the station, there are regular services to destinations such as Austria, Belarus, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Poland, Russia, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. Among these trains are international trains of the [Nederlandse Spoorwegen](/wiki/Nederlandse_Spoorwegen "Nederlandse Spoorwegen") and [Deutsche Bahn](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") to [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), [Eurostar](/wiki/Eurostar "Eurostar") services to [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp"), [Brussels](/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") and [London](/wiki/London "London") and [ICE](/wiki/Intercity_Express "Intercity Express") services to [Cologne](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne") and [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt").^[\[247\]](#cite_note-248)^^[\[248\]](#cite_note-249)^^[\[249\]](#cite_note-250)^{#cite_ref-250}  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Airport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Schiphol_Airport_Pier_D_%287325966610%29.jpg/220px-Schiphol_Airport_Pier_D_%287325966610%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Schiphol_Airport_Pier_D_(7325966610).jpg) [Amsterdam Airport Schiphol](/wiki/Amsterdam_Airport_Schiphol "Amsterdam Airport Schiphol") ranks as Europe's third-busiest airport for passenger traffic.

[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol](/wiki/Amsterdam_Airport_Schiphol "Amsterdam Airport Schiphol") is less than 20 minutes by train from [Amsterdam Centraal station](/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_station "Amsterdam Centraal station") and is served by domestic and international intercity trains, such as [Eurostar](/wiki/Eurostar "Eurostar") and [EuroCity](/wiki/EuroCity "EuroCity"). Schiphol is the largest airport in the Netherlands, the third-largest in Europe, and the 14th-largest in the world in terms of passengers. It handles over 68 million passengers per year and is the home base of four airlines, [KLM](/wiki/KLM "KLM"), [Transavia](/wiki/Transavia "Transavia"), [Martinair](/wiki/Martinair "Martinair") and [Arkefly](/wiki/Arkefly "Arkefly").^[\[250\]](#cite_note-251)^ As of 2014^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit)^, Schiphol was the fifth [busiest airport in the world](/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic "World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic") measured by international passenger numbers.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-passengerrank-252)^ This airport is 4 meters below sea level.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-253)^ Although Schiphol is internationally known as Amsterdam Schiphol Airport it lies in the neighbouring municipality of Haarlemmermeer, southwest of the city.{#cite_ref-253}  

### Cycling {#Cycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Cycling")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Bycicles_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-Bycicles_Amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bycicles_Amsterdam.jpg) Barges regularly pull bicycles from the bottom of the canals in Amsterdam. Many residents discard old bicycles by throwing them into the canals.  
Main article: [Cycling in Amsterdam](/wiki/Cycling_in_Amsterdam "Cycling in Amsterdam")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Amsterdam_-_Bicycles_-_1058.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_-_Bicycles_-_1058.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amsterdam_-_Bicycles_-_1058.jpg) Police bicyclist crossing a bridge over the Prinsengracht [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Bicyclist_at_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-Bicyclist_at_Amsterdam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bicyclist_at_Amsterdam.jpg) Bicyclist at Amsterdam

Amsterdam is one of the most [bicycle-friendly](/wiki/Bicycle-friendly "Bicycle-friendly") large cities in the world and is a centre of [bicycle culture](/wiki/Bicycle_culture "Bicycle culture") with good facilities for cyclists such as bike paths and [bike racks](/wiki/Bicycle_stand "Bicycle stand"), and several guarded bike storage garages (*fietsenstalling*) which can be used.

According to the most recent figures published by the Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS), in 2015 the 442,693 households (850,000 residents) in Amsterdam together owned 847,000 bicycles -- 1.91 bicycles per household.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-254)^ Theft is widespread---in 2011, about 83,000 bicycles were stolen in Amsterdam.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-255)^ Bicycles are used by all socio-economic groups because of their convenience, Amsterdam's small size, the 400 km (249 mi) of bike paths,^[\[255\]](#cite_note-256)^ the flat terrain, and the inconvenience of driving an automobile.^[\[256\]](#cite_note-257)^{#cite_ref-257}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Agnietenkapel_Gate.jpg/220px-Agnietenkapel_Gate.jpg)](/wiki/File:Agnietenkapel_Gate.jpg) The Agnietenkapel Gate at the [University of Amsterdam](/wiki/University_of_Amsterdam "University of Amsterdam"), founded in 1632 as the Athenaeum Illustre

Amsterdam has two universities: the [University of Amsterdam](/wiki/University_of_Amsterdam "University of Amsterdam") (*Universiteit van Amsterdam* , UvA), and the *[Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam](/wiki/Vrije_Universiteit_Amsterdam "Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam")* (VU). Other institutions for higher education include an art school -- [Gerrit Rietveld Academie](/wiki/Gerrit_Rietveld_Academie "Gerrit Rietveld Academie"), a [university of applied sciences](/wiki/Vocational_university#Netherlands "Vocational university") -- the [Hogeschool van Amsterdam](/wiki/Hogeschool_van_Amsterdam "Hogeschool van Amsterdam"), and the [Amsterdamse Hogeschool voor de Kunsten](/wiki/Amsterdamse_Hogeschool_voor_de_Kunsten "Amsterdamse Hogeschool voor de Kunsten"). Amsterdam's [International Institute of Social History](/wiki/International_Institute_of_Social_History "International Institute of Social History") is one of the world's largest documentary and research institutions concerning [social history](/wiki/Social_history "Social history"), and especially the [history of the labour movement](/wiki/Labor_history_(discipline) "Labor history (discipline)"). Amsterdam's [Hortus Botanicus](/wiki/Hortus_Botanicus_(Amsterdam) "Hortus Botanicus (Amsterdam)"), founded in the early 17th century, is one of the oldest botanical gardens in the world,^[\[257\]](#cite_note-Hortus-258)^ with many old and rare specimens, among them the [coffee plant](/wiki/Coffee "Coffee") that served as the parent for the entire [coffee culture](/wiki/Coffee_culture "Coffee culture") in Central and South America.^[\[258\]](#cite_note-he-259)^{#cite_ref-he_259-0}

There are over 200 primary schools in Amsterdam.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-260)^ Some of these primary schools base their teachings on particular pedagogic theories like the various [Montessori](/wiki/Maria_Montessori "Maria Montessori") schools. The biggest Montessori high school in Amsterdam is the [Montessori Lyceum Amsterdam](/wiki/Montessori_Lyceum_Amsterdam "Montessori Lyceum Amsterdam"). Many schools, however, are based on religion. This used to be primarily Roman Catholicism and various Protestant denominations, but with the influx of Muslim immigrants, there has been a rise in the number of Islamic schools. Jewish schools can be found in the southern suburbs of Amsterdam.{#cite_ref-260}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Overzicht%2C_natuurstenen_voorgevel%2C_een_middenrisaliet_met_attiek_-_Amsterdam_-_20408818_-_RCE.jpg/220px-Overzicht%2C_natuurstenen_voorgevel%2C_een_middenrisaliet_met_attiek_-_Amsterdam_-_20408818_-_RCE.jpg)](/wiki/File:Overzicht,_natuurstenen_voorgevel,_een_middenrisaliet_met_attiek_-_Amsterdam_-_20408818_-_RCE.jpg) [Barlaeus Gymnasium](/wiki/Barlaeus_Gymnasium "Barlaeus Gymnasium")

Amsterdam is noted for having five independent grammar schools (Dutch: gymnasia), the [Vossius Gymnasium](/wiki/Vossius_Gymnasium "Vossius Gymnasium"), [Barlaeus Gymnasium](/wiki/Barlaeus_Gymnasium "Barlaeus Gymnasium"), St. [Ignatius Gymnasium](/wiki/Ignatius_Gymnasium "Ignatius Gymnasium"), [Het 4e Gymnasium](/wiki/Het_4e_Gymnasium "Het 4e Gymnasium") and the Cygnus Gymnasium where a classical curriculum including [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") and [classical Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek") is taught. Though believed until recently by many to be an anachronistic and elitist concept that would soon die out, the gymnasia have recently experienced a revival, leading to the formation of a fourth and fifth grammar school in which the three aforementioned schools participate. Most secondary schools in Amsterdam offer a variety of different levels of education in the same school. The city also has various colleges ranging from art and design to politics and economics which are mostly also available for students coming from other countries.

Schools for foreign nationals in Amsterdam include the [Amsterdam International Community School](/wiki/Amsterdam_International_Community_School "Amsterdam International Community School"), [British School of Amsterdam](/wiki/British_School_of_Amsterdam "British School of Amsterdam"), [Albert Einstein International School Amsterdam](/wiki/Albert_Einstein_International_School_Amsterdam "Albert Einstein International School Amsterdam"), [Lycée Vincent van Gogh La Haye-Amsterdam](/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Vincent_van_Gogh_La_Haye-Amsterdam "Lycée Vincent van Gogh La Haye-Amsterdam") primary campus (French school), [International School of Amsterdam](/wiki/International_School_of_Amsterdam "International School of Amsterdam"), and the [Japanese School of Amsterdam](/wiki/Japanese_School_of_Amsterdam "Japanese School of Amsterdam").

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Media")\]

Amsterdam is a prominent centre for national and international media. Some locally based newspapers include *[Het Parool](/wiki/Het_Parool "Het Parool")* , a national daily paper; *[De Telegraaf](/wiki/De_Telegraaf "De Telegraaf")* , the largest Dutch daily newspaper; the daily newspapers *[Trouw](/wiki/Trouw "Trouw")* , *[de Volkskrant](/wiki/De_Volkskrant "De Volkskrant")* and *[NRC](/wiki/NRC_(newspaper) "NRC (newspaper)")* ; *[De Groene Amsterdammer](/wiki/De_Groene_Amsterdammer "De Groene Amsterdammer")* , a weekly newspaper; the free newspapers *[Metro](/wiki/Metro_(Dutch_newspaper) "Metro (Dutch newspaper)")* and *[The Holland Times](/wiki/The_Holland_Times "The Holland Times")* (printed in English).

Amsterdam is home to the second-largest Dutch commercial TV group [SBS Broadcasting Group](/wiki/SBS_Broadcasting_Group "SBS Broadcasting Group"), consisting of TV stations [SBS 6](/wiki/SBS_6 "SBS 6"), [Net 5](/wiki/Net_5 "Net 5"), and [Veronica](/wiki/Veronica_(TV_channel) "Veronica (TV channel)"). However, Amsterdam is not considered 'the media city of the Netherlands'. The town of [Hilversum](/wiki/Hilversum "Hilversum"), 30 km (19 mi) south-east of Amsterdam, has been crowned with this unofficial title. Hilversum is the principal centre for radio and television broadcasting in the Netherlands. [Radio Netherlands](/wiki/Radio_Netherlands_Worldwide "Radio Netherlands Worldwide"), heard worldwide via shortwave radio since the 1920s, is also based there. Hilversum is home to an extensive complex of audio and television studios belonging to the national broadcast production company NOS, as well as to the studios and offices of all the Dutch public broadcasting organisations and many commercial TV production companies.

In 2012, the music video for "Live My Life" by Far East Movement was filmed in various parts of Amsterdam.

Several movies have been filmed in Amsterdam, including the [James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond") film *[Diamonds Are Forever](/wiki/Diamonds_Are_Forever_(film) "Diamonds Are Forever (film)")* , *[Ocean's Twelve](/wiki/Ocean%27s_Twelve "Ocean's Twelve")* , *[Girl with a Pearl Earring](/wiki/Girl_with_a_Pearl_Earring_(film) "Girl with a Pearl Earring (film)")* , *[Kidnapping Mr. Heineken](/wiki/Kidnapping_Freddy_Heineken "Kidnapping Freddy Heineken")* , *[Layer Cake](/wiki/Layer_Cake_(film) "Layer Cake (film)")* and *[The Hitman's Bodyguard](/wiki/The_Hitman%27s_Bodyguard "The Hitman's Bodyguard")* . Amsterdam is also featured in [John Green](/wiki/John_Green "John Green")'s book *[The Fault in Our Stars](/wiki/The_Fault_in_Our_Stars "The Fault in Our Stars")* , which was made into [a film](/wiki/The_Fault_in_Our_Stars_(film) "The Fault in Our Stars (film)") that also partly takes place in Amsterdam.^[\[260\]](#cite_note-261)^{#cite_ref-261}  

Housing {#Housing}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Housing")\]

From the late 1960s onwards many buildings in Amsterdam have been [squatted](/wiki/Squatting "Squatting") both for housing and for use as social centres.^[\[261\]](#cite_note-Owens-262)^ A number of these squats have legalised and become well known, such as [OCCII](/wiki/OCCII "OCCII"), [OT301](/wiki/OT301 "OT301"), [Paradiso](/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)") and [Vrankrijk](/wiki/Vrankrijk "Vrankrijk").{#cite_ref-Owens_262-0}
